item.title: 'I am on a mission to make you all proud': Captain Harry Kane sees it as his duty to restore faith in England
item.description: The England captain will lead Gareth Southgate’s squad, who have the giant task of trying to repair this country’s tattered reputation following the embarrassing showings in 2014 and 2016.
item.content:encoded:
Harry Kane has fired a resounding message to the nation as England get set to depart for the World Cup: we’ll make you proud again.

The England captain will lead Gareth Southgate’s squad, who have the giant task of trying to repair this country’s tattered reputation following the embarrassing showings at the 2014 World Cup and Euro 2016.

Kane was part of the England side who suffered global humiliation at the hands of Iceland in France two years ago.

But the Tottenham striker is on a personal mission to restore the English public’s faith in their national team as he leads the Three Lions in battle.

‘One hundred per cent we want to make the nation proud of the St George’s flag again,’ said Kane. ‘I am proud to be English and I would do anything for my country. Football plays such a big part in that and to make the fans proud and the country proud would be an incredible feeling.

‘We feel that we can do that, so all we can do is fight on the pitch and give 120 per cent in every game and wear that badge with pride. I am sure the country will take to that.’


Fresh from signing a new £90million six-year contract with Tottenham last week, Kane will go into the tournament free of any distractions.

A prolific tournament would only have intensified persistent speculation linking him with Real Madrid.

Of course, the interest remains. Kane and Real look a natural fit. But Kane is genuinely happy in north London, he wouldn’t have signed otherwise.

Eventually, a move to Spain may become a reality, particularly if his career continues on its current trajectory and Tottenham’s trophy drought drags on.

But, at least for now, Kane is seeking success in the Tottenham white he adorns at the moment.

Winning silverware with Tottenham seems a far more realistic opportunity than ending England’s 52-year wait for a major trophy.

Not that you’d know it judging by the England captain’s optimism.

‘It is hard to look beyond the World Cup — I don’t think any player would tell you any different,’ Kane said.

‘It is the one competition that everybody dreams of winning. That is the No 1, first and foremost.

‘Obviously I understand you have got the Champions League and Premier League. There are so many big competitions and they are every season.

‘But for me I don’t think it gets much bigger than the World Cup.

‘I would be surprised if the majority of players did not say that the World Cup is the biggest sporting event in the world.

‘I would love to win everything with Tottenham, but for me personally the World Cup outweighs them all.’

It will be interesting to see how Kane juggles his captaincy duties with shouldering the burden of England’s hopes in front of goal.

Despite his quiet persona, Kane insists he’ll have no qualms about laying down the line to his team-mates.

He said: ‘I can do rollickings. I’ve always been someone who is vocal to push players, to push myself. I try to lead by example.

‘When players are having a good or bad day, there are players around who can see that and do something about it.’

But it is in front of goal where Kane is expected to have the greatest impact over the coming weeks.

He has scored 13 goals in 24 international appearances, which is impressive. However, the 24-year-old is yet to score in a major tournament for England.

Of course, he’s only played in one — the ill-fated Euro 2016 campaign. But given that he also fired blanks in the European Under 21 Championship in 2015, Kane knows that serious questions will be asked if he fails to hit the target again.

‘It’s something I want to change, hopefully this summer. I’ve always felt you go through spells,’ the striker added.

‘The ball goes in, sometimes it doesn’t — like August every year for me. That’s part of the game.

‘But I always look at my game and see how I can get better. So that’s big tournaments.

'Obviously that’s only one tournament for me, but there is the U21s as well. I want to score in tournament football and that is what I will try to do.’

item.title: Liam Plunkett will not be touring Sri Lanka with England... because he's getting married
item.description: EXCLUSIVE BY RICHARD GIBSON: Liam Plunkett is to miss England’s autumn tour of Sri Lanka to get married. Plunkett, 33, arranged his wedding to American partner Emeleah Erb for October 13
item.content:encoded:
Liam Plunkett is to miss England’s autumn tour of Sri Lanka to get married. 

Plunkett, 33, arranged his wedding to American partner Emeleah Erb for October 13 based on the initial tour schedule sent to the ECB by their counterparts at Cricket Sri Lanka. 

That date originally fell during the three-match Test series while the five one-day internationals and one-off Twenty20 international were set for November. 


However, the Sri Lankan board then flipped the series, meaning that whiteball specialist Plunkett’s big day in the Cotswolds now coincides with the second ODI in Dambulla. 

England captain Eoin Morgan rearranged his own wedding to Tara Ridgway due to the alterations. 

But Plunkett was much further down the road in terms of planning with more than 60 guests booked to fly in from the United States, so will not travel when the tour party sets off on September 30. 

While the Yorkshire fast bowler’s place in next year’s World Cup squad appears secure — he was comfortably England’s leading wicket-taker in ODIs in 2017 — it is another disruption to preparations for Morgan’s team and will provide opportunities for players like the Curran brothers Tom and Sam plus Jake Ball to stake their claims. 

Plunkett has played a key role in England’s rise to number one status in 50-over cricket, as the attacking weapon employed to disrupt opponents through the middle of innings. 

He took two wickets on Sunday but at a cost of a hefty 85 runs as Scotland completed one of the great upsets in Edinburgh, with the accomplished tail-ender stranded on 47 not out at non-striker’s end.

England begin their five-match series with Australia tomorrow without injured duo Ben Stokes and Chris Woakes, and with the bowlers that remain now under scrutiny with less than a year to go until they begin another tilt at winning a maiden global ODI trophy on home soil. 

As long as they rectify the mistakes made north of the border, the World Cup favourites should once again be too powerful for Australia. 

England secured the fifth of six straight series wins by a whopping 4-1 margin Down Under in January and the Australians have been severely weakened by the loss of major personnel such as David Warner, Steve Smith, Mitchell Starc and Pat Cummins since then. 

But tougher challenges in maintaining the overall winning momentum lie ahead against India next month, followed by that trip to Sri Lanka where England have been dire in bilateral fixtures, winning just six of 21. 

They will attempt to improve that record without Plunkett, barring any move by the hierarchy to add him for the final two matches of the series. 

However, that is unlikely given how tough it can be to acclimatise to the humid conditions. 

October has proved a popular month for England players to get married in recent times. 

Stokes, Jason Roy and Jos Buttler all tied the knot in October 2017 but England’s Test captain Joe Root and Carrie Cotterell have bucked the trend by plumping for winter nuptials between the end of the Sri Lanka tour and the one to the Caribbean in early 2019.

item.title: The heat is on! England face dramatic rise in temperature for World Cup opener against Tunisia in Volgograd
item.description: MATT LAWTON AND SAMI MOKBEL: England could be forced to cope with a dramatic rise in temperature when they transfer from their training base to Volgograd for their opening game.
item.content:encoded:
England's footballers could be forced to cope with a dramatic rise in temperature when they transfer from their World Cup training base to Volgograd for their opening game.

Gareth Southgate’s squad on Tuesday head to Repino, close to the Finnish border, with the temperature expected to be as low as 15°C for their first training session on Wednesday.

But they then travel more than 1,000 miles south to Volgograd for their first group game against Tunisia on Monday with the mercury expected to rise as high as 33°C there by the end of this week.


A more southerly training base in Sochi had been considered by the FA but Southgate thought it too hot when he visited the city that hosted the 2014 Winter Olympics. Instead, the England manager opted for Repino after a pre-tournament build-up at St George’s Park. 

And while the unusually warm temperatures here in the UK will have assisted England’s players in becoming acclimatised, Volgograd could present a major challenge. It could even be significantly hotter by the time they meet their north African opposition.

According to sources, Southgate and his staff are unconcerned and believe this England side is good enough to dictate the pace of the game against Tunisia.

item.title: McLaren consider loaning out rising British star Lando Norris as they look for him to gain racing experience
item.description: McLaren are open to offers to turn Lando Norris into Britain’s next Formula One star this season, possibly in time for the British Grand Prix next month. Norris has recently been scouted by Toro Rosso.
item.content:encoded:
McLaren are open to offers to turn Lando Norris into Britain’s next Formula One star this season, possibly in time for the British Grand Prix next month.

The team are keen to blood their 18-year-old test driver, despite recently turning down a race seat for him at Toro Rosso. 

That deal collapsed because Toro Rosso wanted to take Norris on a long-term basis, which was deemed unacceptable by McLaren bosses.


But it is understood that if Toro Rosso, or another team, could find space for him at any of the remaining 14 races of the season without condition, McLaren would let him go on loan.

They would then pull him out of his current commitments in Formula Two, which he leads by 27 points going into the next race in France, to focus on his grand prix future.

‘We would like him to get experience somewhere,’ said McLaren chief executive Zak Brown.

‘Lando is a McLaren driver and we think he has a bright future here, but if an opportunity came elsewhere we would seriously consider it. But we have got no interest in letting Lando go anywhere long term.’

If he made his debut this season, Norris would become Britain’s youngest ever Formula One driver.

Norris is in contention for a McLaren race seat next year, either as a replacement for Fernando Alonso, if the double world champion quits the sport, or for the Belgian driver Stoffel Vandoorne.

Meanwhile, Lewis Hamilton returned to England on Monday for consultation with his Mercedes team after losing the world championship lead to Ferrari’s Sebastian Vettel in Canada on Sunday.

The Briton finished fifth and now trails his German rival by a point.

Hamilton said: ‘It is tough when you don’t get the result you have worked for. It is about lifting each other up and pulling together because there is still a long way to go.

‘We can only prepare the best we can to minimise the bad days and capitalise on the better ones.’

item.title: They say it's an impossible job... but Gareth Southgate bucks the trend
item.description: MARTIN SAMUEL: What England have not had recently is a vision: a manager with a philosophy and a willingness to implement real change. With Gareth Southgate, this could be different.
item.content:encoded:
It is not them, strangely enough; it’s him. If there is an unfamiliar lightness about England’s chances at the World Cup, a cautious optimism that this one might not end in ritual humiliation, it is down to Gareth Southgate, the manager, more than his squad.

Nothing wrong with the players, but we’ve had good players. We’ve had better players than this group, frankly, and quite recently, too. The results may have been disappointing but only a football illiterate thinks that the ‘golden generation’ England team couldn’t play.

They may not have been best served by their managers, or by good fortune, but they were players. Most, if not all, would walk into this team right now.

Yet what England have not had recently is a vision: a manager with a philosophy and a willingness to implement real change. The foreign appointments, Sven Goran Eriksson and Fabio Capello, were short-term and results-based. Steve McClaren was a prevaricator who abandoned his thoughts of revolution after one setback in Croatia.

Roy Hodgson’s occasional boldness seemed forced, as if his heart wasn’t really in it. Sam Allardyce failed to launch. Southgate is different. More adventurous, braver than many believed, with a clear sense of where he wants this team to be heading. We know what he is working towards, even if he may not have the personnel yet to deliver it.


And he makes sense, too, off the field, as well as on. It is not just his style of play that has earned plaudits, but his style of management. 

The way he has gently, but firmly, ushered several big names out of the picture without everything around him bursting into flames, the way he has redirected the many random missiles launched his way, from controversial tattoos to government interventions and talk of boycotts.

It is a well-worn line that managing England is an impossible job — another documentary with that title is scheduled for next weekend — but Southgate is bucking that cliche with simple reason. 

Capello lost his way as the 2010 tournament approached, trying to bring players out of retirement and signing up for a counter-productive commercial opportunity, but Southgate grows more impressively measured and focused with each outing.

He resists bandwagons and populist trends, he skirts traps. He is so much more than a nice guy, or a company stooge. Increasingly, he is a man who inspires faith and confidence: a truly admirable figurehead.

Of course, this means little if England fail to emerge from the group.

Southgate is not here to play the World Cup in theory. There has to be finite, tangible progress in Russia; a genuine sense that things are better than before. Southgate can be articulate in front of a microphone and progressive on the tactics board, he can be convincing in public and popular with his players, but if England fail to get past Tunisia and Panama, he is going to be a hard sell for next season.

Yet if the worst was to happen, even if it renders his position untenable, he is likely to escape without being turned into a vegetable or a wally.

Why? We’re in it with him. His views are our views. The media, large swathes of the public, the professional game. What he is doing is widely understood and supported, eminently rational and rooted in logic. 

The phasing out of Wayne Rooney, dropping Joe Hart and Jack Wilshere, playing three at the back, moving Raheem Sterling nearer to Harry Kane, reinventing Kyle Walker to make room for Kieran Trippier — these are arguments that make sense and have, largely, come off.

His looser discipline, the room he allows his players, the responsibility he affords them, fighting the battles he can win, existing comfortably with those he can’t — in his man-management methods Southgate epitomises the change in international strategy. 

After Capello, who now believes an old-school disciplinarian would work? Had the Italian lasted until the 2012 European Championship, even he would undoubtedly have adjusted the thinking that sucked the life out of England’s group in South Africa.

Yet while Capello may have evolved into a better England manager for his first tournament experience, he was never going to be greatly interested in England’s production line. Like Eriksson, he had better things to do than study the Under 21s, or the teenagers below.

When Allardyce talked of introducing a new name to the England ranks in 2016, he meant manipulating the international rules to pick Steven Nzonzi, who is French. 

How short-sighted was that? As a former age-group coach, Southgate, one feels, is engaged and committed to the pathway in a way many predecessors simply were not. 

Only Nigeria have a younger squad at this World Cup — yet England may still be youthful in 2020 or 2022 if Southgate remains in charge, and new faces continue to be added.

The potential of youth is hard to tame. So this is not to say nothing will go wrong, or could go wrong for England in Russia. Tunisia are organised and lively and will be tricky first-game opponents. England cannot afford an off-day in the heat of Volgograd on Monday.

Yet the main reason to hope all goes to plan is that progress to the last 16, or beyond — and there is no reason England cannot reach the last eight here — should secure another two years of Southgate’s vision, at least. 

With more good young players coming from the age-group teams, perhaps England will be better placed to carry out plans first visualised in Russia at the 2020 European Championship.

After so much inconsistency of thought, English football could do with more of Southgate’s calm-inducing logic. Clarity and optimism have hardly been our default settings, after all. 

 

Why Wembley is ideal

These days, the script dictates that Wembley is corporate and dull and England would be much better eschewing the national stadium for the provinces. 

The atmosphere at Elland Road last week was certainly noisy. The many tributes, however, overlooked one salient fact — England’s Manchester United players, Marcus Rashford and Phil Jones, and later substitute Jesse Lingard, were booed. 

Not with great venom or for a prolonged period, but loudly enough to be noticeable and without the players doing anything to provoke it. They just had to be present and play for Manchester United.

And it didn’t matter because this was a friendly, England were quickly on top and Rashford was outstanding from the start.

It will not, however, always be that way. If Wembley is sold and England do have to play some home matches on the road each season, they will not all be strolls like Thursday’s game. There will be occasions when England are poor, or struggling, have a difficult qualifying group or desperately need a win.

Meaning there will be occasions when fans arrive dissatisfied. Football has moved on since England were last on a domestic tour.

It is more than a decade since the national team returned to Wembley and the English game has grown considerably more tribal in that time. Fans are defined by who they despise as much as those they love. 

When the ska anthem Liquidator by Harry J. All Stars is played at Stamford Bridge now, the locals chant about hating Tottenham before they even mention Chelsea. It is ridiculous.

So, the idea that England’s players will be welcomed, supported and garlanded in the provinces is presumptuous. If that had been England needing to win against Belgium last week and Jones had been skinned by Eden Hazard as he was at Wembley on FA Cup final day, Elland Road could have turned very inhospitable. 

Wembley might not be ideal — but it is largely a safe space. 

 

Vieira is moving in the right direction

Ideally, the satellite clubs of the City Football Group feed the biggest of them all, Manchester City. So Aaron Mooy is recruited by Melbourne City, impresses, is signed by Manchester City and eventually by Huddersfield. 

His career path is straightforward, either way. He makes the grade in Manchester, or their status secures him a career elsewhere in England, for an enhanced fee. It’s a win-win for club and player.

The same should apply to managers, but it is more complex. Patrick Vieira’s experience with New York City could prepare him to succeed Pep Guardiola in Manchester one day. 

Yet until the standard of Major League Soccer improves, little comes guaranteed. Would Manchester City take a chance on a coach whose sole position was in MLS? Probably not. Bob Bradley is the only American to manage a Premier League side and his time at Swansea did not end well.

So Vieira has done the right thing, swapping New York for Nice. A successful time in Ligue 1 or beyond will give him experience of coaching in a major European league, while his years in New York maintain the connection with City. 

As long as he has departed on good terms — and there is nothing to suggest otherwise — leaving may actually enhance his chances of becoming Manchester City manager one day. 

 

Window shutting on Villa's Grealish plan

Aston Villa hope to wring £40million from the sale of Jack Grealish this summer, to stave off economic oblivion. Unfortunately, everything is against them.

Their acute financial difficulties are very public knowledge, meaning suitors are aware they can drive the hardest bargain. 

Equally, birdbrain chairmen across the leagues voted to cut short the transfer window, meaning there is less time for a deal to be done. Villa might be made to sweat as the new season approaches, knowing the door will soon shut. This was a ludicrously impulsive judgment call and was always going to lead to complications.

The unexpected collapse of Nabil Fekir’s move from Lyon to Liverpool shows how difficult it can be to get a transfer over the line — even with £53m on the table.

Liverpool were doing it all right, trying to get their business completed early, and the deal was so far advanced Fekir had even been allowed to select a shirt number. 

Now they are back to square one. With the World Cup about to begin, alternate targets might be a month away from the negotiation process. Support for an early deadline was unanimous, but clubs may soon taste the reality and it will be far from pleasant for all.

 

For the record, my composite golden generation/current England team would be (4-3-2-1): Hart; G Neville, Ferdinand, Terry, A Cole; Gerrard, Hargreaves, Lampard; Scholes, Rooney; Owen. 

And my starting XI against Tunisia would be: Pickford; Walker, Stones, Maguire; Trippier, Henderson, Young; Lingard, Sterling, Alli; Kane.

So slightly different.

 

Well, that didn’t take long. Only 24 hours after last week’s column about the shallow boasts of marginal gains that always follow England to World Cups and Martin Glenn, the FA chief executive, jumped straight in. 

‘I think we’ve never been better prepared,’ he announced. Just to say, I’m also available for psychic healings, seances, spiritual gatherings and the reading of tea leaves, as long as there are biscuits.

 

Cup doesn't have a leg to stand on

Extra time will not be a feature of EFL Cup ties from next season. 

If the game is drawn on 90 minutes, it will progress directly to a penalty shootout. This is good for tired legs, not so helpful to the spectacle. 

An overmatched underdog could start to play for penalties from half-time. There is every chance performances will become more cautious or negative.

Yet, in the face of this, the two-leg semi-final remains — now a complete anomaly. Every other round is decided on the night, truncated like never before. 

Yet one tie, in one specific round, takes a minimum three hours to complete in game time and over a week between the fixtures. Competitions should at least make sense. This doesn’t.

 

We may be in for another round of crazy golf at the US Open

In 2004, when the US Open last went to Shinnecock Hills, the average round was 78.7.

It is widely agreed that the USGA lost control of the course that week.

The seventh green was so slick that 80 per cent of approach shots failed to hold. This week, the tournament returns to Shinnecock and paranoia among the professionals is high.

The US Open has always prided itself on being a different challenge — quirkier, less hospitable, it drags the cosy Tour out of its comfort zone.

The aim is for the winner to be level par.

Under Mike Davis, however, too much trickery has courted disaster. In 2015, at Chambers Bay, members of the European Tour claimed that had the wind blown more strongly on the Pacific Coast — as it usually does in June — no ball would have stayed on the green and the US Open would have been abandoned.

The rough at Erin Hills in 2017 was so punitive, only the horrified reaction of players in the Monday practice round made the USGA see sense, cut the fescue grass and save the competition.

Now we await the horrors of Shinnecock. Major championship golf should be a test. It shouldn’t, however, be crazy.

 

Tyson Fury should come out for his next fight dressed as Widow Twanky and at least be honest about it. If fans are paying for a pantomime, they should get a pantomime.

 

Great news for Tottenham that Harry Kane has joined Mauricio Pochettino in committing his long term future to the club — with one proviso. 

That this is a genuine and meaningful obligation on Daniel Levy’s part and not just a means of extracting an extra £50m from Real Madrid if an offer ever comes.

 

The draw for the first round of the Carabao Cup will be held in Vietnam. As the organisers should also be if there was any justice.

item.title: England midfielder Fabian Delph reveals meditation is the secret to his success after impressive Manchester City season earned him World Cup call
item.description: Fabian Delph says his decision to start meditating and stop eating red meat helped him kick-start his career. The Manchester City midfielder was one of Gareth Southgate’s shock picks for the World Cup.
item.content:encoded:
Fabian Delph says his decision to start meditating and stop eating red meat helped him kick-start his career.

The Manchester City midfielder was one of Gareth Southgate’s shock picks in his final 23-man England squad.

Delph emerged as a key player for Pep Guardiola’s side last season — culminating in his selection for the World Cup — and the 28-year-old says two lifestyle choices were integral to his form.


He said: ‘I stopped eating red meat but still eat other meat. I’ve changed my diet in terms of getting it more balanced, more healthy by eating more greens, more vegetables — and I’ve cut out sugar. 

'It’s helped me tremendously. I kept picking up muscle injuries. I was obviously getting older. I have always trained with crazy intensity.

‘And it was all about trying to find a balance. It was a case of finding the right nutrition.

‘It’s worked. I only had a couple of niggles all season which is fantastic. In terms of meditation, for me it is just breathing techniques, learning to be still, to control your thought processes, it calms you down.

‘Gael Clichy, who was at the club (City), does a lot of meditation. He recommended it to me because I was such an all-action guy. It has calmed me down.’

item.title: 'Our son has opened up a can of worms... but don't blame him': Brad Shields' parents defend his switch from All Blacks to England
item.description: WILL KELLEHER EXCLUSIVE INTERVIEW: Brad Shields’ family have bitten their tongue for too long. Now they want to defend their son’s controversial switch from New Zealand to England.
item.content:encoded:
Brad Shields’ family have bitten their tongue for too long. Now they want to defend their son’s controversial switch from New Zealand to England.

On Saturday the back-rower became the 1,399th player to play for England, coming on as a 36th-minute substitute at lock for Nick Isiekwe. That Shields has been parachuted in without playing a minute on these shores has angered some.

Much has been written about the 27-year-old, the to-and-fro surrounding his release, and his choice to change allegiance. His parents, Nigel and Danielle, have kept their counsel — but now want to set the record straight.


‘It’s hard to read about it,’ his mother, 56, exclusively tells Sportsmail.

‘I defy anyone in any career who has an opportunity and a dream like this not to choose the path that would give them that. It happens in any career, in any sport.

‘There’s lot of people born in different countries who end up representing an adopted country.

‘Bradley did not pick himself. The selectors in England saw something in Bradley that they wanted or needed in their team, and the selectors in New Zealand didn’t so didn’t pick him.

‘That is their prerogative. It is what it is.’

A typically to-the-point rebuttal from honest Kiwi folk.

Here’s Dad, 54-year-old Nigel: ‘He may have opened up a can of worms but he certainly didn’t plan it.

‘He has been mature, kept his dignity, and kept the moral high-ground if there was one.

‘He was caught between a rock and a hard place. Bradley is not going to gloat that’s for sure.’

‘I can understand a little bit of frustration on the English side,’ Danielle adds.

‘It’s not his bug to bear if he got chosen and someone else didn’t.’

And the Shields’ want everyone to know one thing – despite reports to the contrary he never turned down the All Blacks as he was never offered a place in their squad recently.

‘We hope everyone moves on,’ Nigel continues.

‘Bradley does too. He wants to play at the highest level he can. There is nothing wrong with that.’

Now that is covered it is worth telling Shields’ fascinating story.

Back in Easter 1991 Danielle was seven months pregnant and intending to travel down from Nigel’s parents’ house near Masterton in New Zealand’s North Island to Christchurch in the south – her and Nigel, who met in the Army, were taking up a posting there.

But Brad had other ideas.

‘I had complications with the pregnancy and Bradley was born at the local hospital in Masterton,’ Danielle explains.

‘He was eight weeks early but we were extremely lucky, he flourished from birth and was only in an incubator for a day.

‘He was a fighter right from the word go.’

‘At the start of Bradley’s life he weighed four-and-a-half pounds, and now he’s 17-and-a-half stone!’ laughs Nigel.

So how did that transformation happen?

‘It must’ve been the meat-pie sandwiches!’ chuckles Dad. ‘And his mother’s nachos!’

Shields owes his new career to his parents. In 1964 Danielle’s family upped-sticks from Rochford, Essex to New Zealand. Her father was a quantity surveyor who saw an opportunity as a ‘Ten Pound Pom’.

In 1966, Nigel’s family moved from Hull too; his dad an aeronautical engineer. Both left England when two years old. 

Whizz forward 40 years and there is Brad; a 14-year-old playing for Taita College 1st XV, three years up.

He had learnt his favourite sport near the Waiouru military camp, 2,500ft up in the hills near Mount Ruapehu – playing barefoot rugby in the freezing cold.

Nigel remembers returning from a tour of Cambodia to a two-year-old Shields.

‘The first thing he said to me was “do you play rugby?”’ Nigel recalls.

‘He was tossing a ball around. I said: “Yep, course I do mate!”

‘All of our kids were given every opportunity to explore and try out different sports.’

They are good at them. Younger brother Nicholas, 25, will represent New Zealand in the World Beach Handball Championships in Russia this summer.

Sister Stacey, 29, is sporty too and cousins Beth Ross and Catherine Shields are rowers. The former will compete for New Zealand in Bulgaria at the World Championships and the latter is at Ohio College and a three-time US National champion.

Brad played U19 regional basketball and formed part of the Black Sox U19 softball team – but rugby was always the dream.

Soon he was a Hurricane in Wellington – following in the footsteps of All Black heroes Jerry Collins, Christian Cullen and Tana Umaga.

In 2012 he was invited to join the world champions. Nigel recollects the Mothers’ Day dinner Brad interrupted – and wants to correct the story from the local paper at the time.

‘It said “luckily Shields is allowed to read his texts at the dinner table”,’ says Nigel.

‘Well, Shields isn’t allowed to read his texts at the dinner table! But he did and gave me a nudge. I said: “Put your phone away Bradley” but he said “no, have a look at this!”  

‘We broke the family rules to read the text. It was from the manager of the All Blacks saying “congratulations, we want you in the camp”.

‘He was a bit nervous as he was only 21 at the time but thought “Wow”. It was the first time we didn’t see him eat!’

The dream was not realised. In retrospect that camp was a sliding doors moment. Sam Cane – now the All Blacks new Richie McCaw figure – twisted Shields’ knee in a training-ground tackle and he was crocked for eight months.

Four years later Shields was re-called, but not selected to play.

In 2015 his parents moved to Surrey, then Berkshire. They now run a 100-acre estate in Stanford Dingley, and Danielle works in the local pub.

Soon Brad, his wife Louise and seven-month old daughter Charley will join them in England.

Mum and Dad cannot wait.

‘We’ve got five grandchildren so it will be nice to have one of them here,’ says Danielle.

‘We miss them terribly. It’s a small world with technology, but our young grandchildren think we live in the TV!’

‘I’ll be able to watch his games with a beer!’ chuckles Nigel.

‘That’s why I enjoyed the Test match on Saturday, I could have a couple of beers and it wasn’t 8am!’

They will fly out to South Africa on Friday hoping to see their son make his full debut in the second Test in Bloemfontein. The England shirts are packed after a first outing on Saturday.

‘We had our jerseys on and a celebratory lunch with some bubbles to mark the occasion,’ says Nigel.

‘It was a very proud day for both of us. We backed the All Blacks as kids but my parents used to back England. I can’t remember wearing an English shirt before.’

‘Apart from 2003!’ Danielle interrupts.

‘For the World Cup final we had a party at our house – we wore England shirts then.’

‘Yes, you can’t support Australia,’ says Nigel.

Come 2019 they may be able to wear the rose with pride watching a World Cup again, but this time with their English son involved.

item.title: Eoin Morgan’s men suffered a shock defeat against Scotland but don’t worry, here’s England’s six-point plan to rule the World!
item.description: PAUL NEWMAN: With England’s one-day series against the old enemy Australia starting on Wednesday, here are six issues they can address to get back on track ahead of next year’s World Cup.
item.content:encoded:
First things first. To be at The Grange on Sunday was a joy. This was a fabulous day for cricket, with Scotland striking a blow for all associate nations so controversially denied their passage to next year’s World Cup.

The Scots thoroughly deserved one of the greatest of upsets, beating a near- invincible England one-day side fair and square in front of just the sort of family audience the ECB so craves from its gimmicky new tournament.

It was a triumph immediately recognised on Monday when Derbyshire announced the signing of century hero Calum MacLeod for the T20 Blast.

With England’s one-day series against the old enemy Australia starting on Wednesday, here are six issues they can address to get back on track ahead of next year’s World Cup on home soil.


1) Play the situation

The defeat in Edinburgh raises serious issues for an England side who simply have to win the World Cup to justify the considerable investment in one-day cricket made by Andrew Strauss and, consequently, the decline in the Test team. England may have undergone a white-ball revolution but need to realise they cannot always hit their way out of trouble.

They must play the situation in front of them. Morgan said after the Scotland loss that they will learn from mistakes playing ‘their way’ but the dismissals of Jonny Bairstow and Moeen Ali when going so well showed they must be more intelligent.

Bairstow was brilliant in making his third straight one-day century but this time he had to go on and win the match. Moeen had salvaged the situation after England lost five wickets for 56 but then gave it away when all he had to do was play sensibly for the rest of the innings. The hard work was done: that’s what England do not seem to grasp.

2) Don’t be dopey

Talking of intelligence, there was no greater lack of it than in the display of Alex Hales, who could be dropped when Ben Stokes returns.

He has been a key component in the rise of England’s white-ball cricket and has scored half-centuries in his last two innings but has the worst game-management of any England player.

He was culpable in Joe Root’s run-out before inexplicably giving his wicket away the very next ball after Morgan was dismissed. It left two new batsmen at the crease at the worst possible time and was the personification of England’s mismanagement.

3) Bowlers need to get up to speed

Yes, the Grange pitch was perfect for batting and yes, the boundaries were very short but there is no way the best one-day side in the world should allow the 13th-ranked team to score 371. Stokes and Chris Woakes were sorely missed but there was a lack of penetration and flat-wicket skills.

Nobody was more worrying than Mark Wood, who is lacking the extreme pace that marked him out as England’s X-factor.

Wood was still bowling around 85-87mph in Edinburgh but he is gun-barrel straight and does not get the bounce of, say, Liam Plunkett. If injuries have taken their toll and he cannot get back up to 90mph then he will struggle to sustain an international career.

Also, giving up red-ball cricket to concentrate on white-ball did not appear immediately to benefit Adil Rashid.

4) Plan for life without Stokes and Woakes

There is no getting around it. The absence of Stokes causes chaos to the balance of all England sides. He is such a valuable cricketer with bat, ball and in the field that his injury leaves him sorely missed.

But England have to get used to it. Various niggles and off-field problems are causing Stokes to miss an alarming amount of cricket and there is a danger that an all-rounder once destined for greatness is drifting.

It was pertinent, too, that Morgan should point out before the Scotland match just how slowly Woakes heals. We are unlikely to see him at all during the Australia series and it could be that striving for extra pace has taken its toll.

This is the second summer running Woakes has gone down with injury and his overseas record renders him a home specialist now. It can only be hoped we haven’t already seen the best of him.

5) Make it count on flat tracks

Perhaps the biggest concern in Scotland was that the defeat came on a perfect batting pitch. It was exactly the sort of surface England have appeared capable of chasing anything on, let alone 372 against a sub-standard Scottish attack.

Record chase or not, they should have won. They should have won last year’s Champions Trophy, too, but were undone in the semi-final against Pakistan on the sort of slow, turning track they could easily come across again with the ICC preparing World Cup wickets with an eye on sub-continental sides.

The last thing England need is to waste opportunities on pitches made for them.

6)... but Look on the bright side!

We also need to keep things in perspective. Life should be about to get much better for England. Australia are in town! The rested Jos Buttler will be back for Wednesday's 50-over match, the first of five, and, with Australia missing their cheating pair, Steve Smith and David Warner, and injured fast bowlers Mitchell Starc, Pat Cummins and Josh Hazlewood, England will be expected to win this series comfortably.

There would be nothing like a 5-0 thrashing of the Aussies to make England forget their embarrassing excursion north of the border.

item.title: Brad Shields has a habit of doing things differently: He could have been on his stag do in Auckland but made his England debut at Ellis Park instead
item.description: EXCLUSIVE: If things had worked out differently, Brad Shields would have been enjoying his belated stag do in Auckland last weekend. Instead, he made his England debut at Ellis Park on Saturday.
item.content:encoded:
If things had worked out differently, Brad Shields would have been enjoying his belated stag do in Auckland last weekend.

Instead, the New Zealand-born backrower made his England debut in the thrilling defeat to the Springboks at Ellis Park.

Shields has a habit of doing things differently. He got married last December but a hectic season meant any stag celebrations would have to wait until the final weekend of May. Instead of cutting loose with his friends, he was hitting tackle bags in South Africa.


‘Yeah, bloody Eddie Jones ruined it all,’ jokes Michael Kainga, best friend and former team-mate of Shields.

In Brad’s absence, his brother Nick stepped in to represent the Shields clan. It’s been an eventful 12 months for the 27-year-old flanker, on and off the field. 

Shields got married to his girlfriend Louise at the end of 2017. His parents Danielle and Nigel, who now reside in Berkshire, were in attendance. Mr and Mrs Shields also welcomed their first child, Charley, into the family.

He captained the Hurricanes against the British and Irish Lions last summer: a pulsating 31-31 draw in the capital.

He’s been on the periphery of New Zealand selection in the past and was called into an All Blacks training squad in 2012 but a chat with Eddie Jones convinced him to up sticks and make the 12,000 mile trip to pursue a shot at Test rugby with England. 

Next season, he will swap Wellington’s Cake Tin for Wasps’ Ricoh Arena. His ancestry, both of his parents were born in England, means he is available for selection immediately.

A gifted sportsman, Shields played his youth rugby for Stokes Valley before enrolling in Taita College, a small institution of about 600 students which competes in the fourth division of the Wellington schools competition.

Shield is now a 17-stone powerhouse blindside who goes by nicknames such as Shieldsy, Braddles and Wolverine but Debbie Elliot, sports coordinator at Taita College, first knew him as Bradley.

‘He was our sports captain in 2008 and when he was deputy head boy at school,’ she recalls.

‘At the same time, he was playing Wellington U20 representative basketball, he was playing senior softball and he was selected for the New Zealand U19 softball team to go an play in Australia.

‘So, he’s done lots of things. He was also the Wellington Colleges’ all-rounder of the year. They have a big ceremony for all college sports students in the Wellington region; so that can be up to 8,000 people.

‘He won the all-rounder of the year for three years in a row.’

His talents were not going unnoticed. Petone are one of the heavy hitters on the Wellington club scene and came calling for his services. Brad’s uncle, Dion Ross, was first team coach. 

His cousin, Jack Ross, still plays for the club. Petone is the third oldest club in New Zealand and has produced the likes of former All Blacks captain Tana Umaga.

Shields was drafted into the club’s first team straight out of school.

Amazingly, he is not the first Petone boy to play for England. That honour belongs to Riki Flutey who represented Wasps, England and the Lions.

Flutey also holds the honour of playing for and against the Lions. Shields could follow suit.

‘We knew that Brad was special when he came to the club,’, says Wayne Smith, chairman of Petone.

‘He was a big lad when he came to the club. He was 6ft 4in at 18, we knew he had the build to make it. Everyone thought he might be our next All Black but unfortunately he didn’t quite make it.’

Shields and his best mate Kainga would earn a call-up to the New Zealand U20 squad for the 2011 Junior World Championship. It was stellar line-up with Beauden Barrett, Brodie Retallick and Sam Cane among their ranks. 

They beat an England team containing Owen Farrell, George Ford and Elliot Daly in the final. Now, Shields is set to wear the Red Rose alongside those same players.

A professional contract with the Hurricanes was the next rung on the ladder. One of his greatest strengths is a remarkable engine. He finished first in the the club’s Surf to Peak challenge in pre-season: a gruelling race beginning with a a 1km sprint followed by a 21km cycle and finishing with a 2km climb to the top of Mount Victoria, the city’s highest point.

‘I always remember we were doing a fitness session in the Wellington academy,’ Kainga recalls.

‘Brad was just smoking everyone. He was just killing it. I always remember the Hurricanes (coaches) were watching. They weren’t watching us… they were just watching him.’

Shields recently became only the 14th player to make 100 appearances for the region. He played a central role when the Hurricanes secured a maiden Super Rugby title in 2016.

This Anglo-Kiwi forward could be running out at Twickenham in next years’s Six Nations, but he has played there before. 

In November 2016, Shields played for the Barbarians against South Africa at England HQ. Eagle-eyed spectators would have noticed the giant flanker was wearing odd socks: one from Stokes Valley, the other from Petone.

‘That in a nutshell tells you how down to earth he is,’ adds Smith.

It’s certainly been a remarkable journey.

‘I actually told a story at his leaving party recently,’ Kainga concludes.

‘We were walking to a (Hurricanes) game (when we were young) and we saw the team bus driving down the hill to the stadium

We saw Thomas Waldrom at the back of the bus and he waved out to us. I remember saying to Brad: “that will be us one day waving out to someone”.

‘A few years later we were doing the same thing on the way to a game. It was pretty bloody cool.’

item.title: Woods was told to pull out but played on one leg over FIVE rounds. No wonder his last major win 10 years ago is known as Tiger's miracle
item.description: ‘It is one of my greatest memories in golf and always will be,’ says Robert Karlsson, his third-round playing partner that week at Torrey Pines.
item.content:encoded:
Ten years on, the astounding manner in which Tiger Woods won the United States Open at Torrey Pines still causes Robert Karlsson, his third-round playing partner that week, to blow air into his cheeks and break into a broad smile.

‘It is one of my greatest memories in golf and always will be,’ says the gentle Swede, a former European No 1 who will be a vice- captain at this year’s Ryder Cup.

‘The idea that a man could win a major championship while so badly injured still causes me to shake my head in wonder. By the time we got to the 17th, Tiger was struggling so badly I asked his caddie Steve Williams whether he thought he would even be able to play the final round, let alone think about winning.


‘The way he put that third round together, the pain he went through, the two eagles he made in the last six holes from impossible places, it’s so special looking back. And the atmosphere, wow! How do you begin to describe that?’

Only when it was over, after Tiger had not only turned up for the final round but a play-off the following day that lasted 19 holes, did the full story of his injury emerge. Of how he arrived at Torrey Pines having played only nine holes since the Masters in April, which he completed in 53 shots.

Of the meeting three weeks earlier with his specialist, who told him to forget all about golf for the rest of the year, as he had a ruptured anterior cruciate ligament in his left knee and two stress fractures of his tibia — and Tiger’s defiant response.

‘You can do what you want with my leg at the end of June, doc,’ he said. ‘But I’m playing the US Open. I’m going to win.’

He seemed like Superman on that Monday afternoon when presented with the trophy but what a price he would pay. It would prove the last of his 14 major championship victories, as wondrous feats gave way to a heart-breaking divorce and its tawdry aftermath.

Now, he’s back again, marking the 10th anniversary as one of the favourites for this year’s edition at Shinnecock Hills.

‘Sitting here, I guess the 10 years have gone by quickly but there were certainly times when I wasn’t well when every second felt like 24 hours,’ said Woods last week. ‘I think there are four major victories that stand out for me because I didn’t miss a putt inside 10 feet at any of them — the 1997 Masters, the 2000 US Open (Pebble Beach), the 2000 Open (St Andrews), and Torrey. But the last one was when I needed to putt like that. I didn’t hit the ball anywhere near as well that week as the other three.’

Is there anyone still out there who thinks he’s got no chance at Shinnecock, that people at 42 don’t suddenly remember how to win majors? If so, let’s rewind to five unforgettable days when he completed mission impossible.

The drama began the Sunday before, when Woods realised he could not rest his ailing knee any longer. ‘I played Big Canyon down the road, the course I grew up on, and I was still trying to work out how I was going to play wearing a knee brace,’ recalled Tiger.

‘So I shot 50-odd for nine holes doing that and, on the drive to Torrey I threw the brace in the trash and said to my trainer, “Now, I have to figure out how I am going to play without it”.’

There was no evidence he had solved the conundrum by the first hole, as he marked down a double-bogey six. Woods stumbled on to card 72 to lie four off the lead.

‘I thought he would withdraw and was amazed when he turned up for the second round,’ said then USGA president Jim Vernon.

On day two, jaws went slack as Woods came home in 30 shots for a 68 to lie tied second with Karlsson. ‘That was the moment when something rather magical began to unfold,’ said USGA chief executive Mike Davis.

Day three has gone down as one of those ‘only Tiger’ days, when the pain was at its height and Karlsson had a ringside seat.

‘On the back nine he hit it so poor because the only way he could actually get through the ball with his knee was by hitting a massive slice off the tee,’ he told Sportsmail. ‘On the 15th he couldn’t do that because there was a tree on the left of the tee. He knew what was coming next. He said to me not to wait for him after he hit his drive. Now he stuck a perfect draw, the best shot he hit all day, but the cost was clear. He stood on the tee just hyperventilating. After I walked on he was still on the tee, trying to recover.’

Woods hit it everywhere over that back nine. On the 13th his drive finished in a toilet. On the 14th he missed the fairway by 50 yards to the right. At the 17th he was short and in a horrible lie in two. None of it was reflected on his scorecard.

‘Everything went for him,’ said Karlsson. ‘He got a free drop from the toilet at the 13th and made an eagle. At the 17th he chipped in. At the 18th he was 80 feet away in two but by then we all knew what was going to happen. I remember watching his putt thinking, surely not, but it kept going and going and fell into the hole. Outside the Ryder Cup, the roar was the loudest I’ve ever heard.’

Yet how could Tiger carry on? ‘That might have been the most incredible thing of all, that he came back for the fourth day,’ said Karlsson. Woods started with a double bogey, and followed it with a bogey. Again he wouldn’t give in.

On the agony went until he got to the 18th, needing a birdie to tie underdog Rocco Mediate, as did playing partner Lee Westwood. Clearly seething after leaving his own 20-foot downhill effort short, the Englishman couldn’t watch as Woods stood over his 15-footer.

‘I didn’t need to watch anyway,’ recalled Westwood. ‘He always holes those putts, doesn’t he?’ One more putt duly dropped and, in a rare contrast of emotion, Woods’s face was creased with rapture, rather than pain. And back we came for a fifth day. Eighteen-hole play-offs staged on Mondays are usually anti- climactic, but not this one.

Three shots behind with eight to play, Mediate benefited from bogeys from Woods at the 11th and 12th and then went ahead with birdies at 14 and 15. Once more, Woods needed a birdie at the 18th to tie; once more he delivered. Now it became sudden-death, and that was where Woods got his hands on the trophy.

Mediate sums up the week. ‘It was five days of controlled insanity,’ he said. ‘And it was the golf experience of a lifetime.’

Two days later, Woods went into hospital to have his knee surgically rebuilt. It would be eight months before he reappeared, but he would never be the same player again. It was the debt owed for perhaps the most courageous US Open victory of all.

item.title: Shinnecock Hills fairways are heaven for Rory McIlroy and the big hitters at the US Open
item.description: DEREK LAWRENSON - WORLD OF GOLF: Of all the surprises thrown at the game in recent years, the sight of generous fairways at Shinnecock Hills might well be the most unexpected.
item.content:encoded:
Rory McIlroy looked as happy as a sand boy and no wonder. Of all the surprises the United States Golf Association have thrown at the game in recent years, the sight of generous fairways for this year’s edition of the US Open at Shinnecock Hills might well be the most unexpected.

While the short and medium hitters are grumbling in the locker room already, asking not unreasonably, ‘What’s happened to the rough, tough bad old US Open?’, McIlroy stressed it’s born of necessity. ‘Imagine if you had this wind, narrow fairways, and ferocious rough?’ he told Sportsmail, during nine holes of practice on Monday.

Actually, we don’t need to imagine. It happened the last time the US Open was in these parts, and the infamous farce of 2004.


He added: ‘They look generous, and they will be if there’s no wind, but go and drop a ball in the rough and see what happens. If you miss them, you’ve got no chance.’

McIlroy has been here a week already and is having a ball. He’s played three other great courses in this privileged part of Long Island — the National, Sebonack and Friar’s Head — as well as a couple of twirls around Shinnecock.

‘What a fantastic part of the world, and particularly at this time of year,’ he enthused. 

QUOTE OF THE WEEK

‘What a cool way to end the day and hole that shot on 18. A lot of good things happened this week. I knew coming in I was swinging really well and had a lot of confidence in my game. Now, it’s about doing it again at the US Open.’

What a cool way to regain the world No 1 spot too, as Dustin Johnson closed out victory by six shots at the St Jude Classic on Sunday by holing his second shot from the fairway at the 18th. In so doing he displaced Justin Thomas at the summit. No player has ever claimed the US Open having won the week before but, given the fairly lenient Shinnecock Hills set-up, Johnson clearly has the opportunity to create history.

For Monday’s round, McIlroy had Spaniard Jon Rahm for company. In between shots he consulted with former American Ryder Cup player Brad Faxon, who’s been advising him on his putting and in the process has become something of a mentor. He also picked the brains of three-time major champion Nick Price, who’s now a voice of sanity on the USGA’s executive committee.

Like every other player, McIlroy spent an inordinate amount of time practising on the severely undulating greens. In the process, it was easy to see how the USGA got them so fast last time they became unfair. This was only Monday but from a position above the 18th green, McIlroy still knocked his first putt from 20 feet almost as far past the hole.

‘Nick was saying they will only get about a foot faster than this,’ he explained, referring to the added distance the ball would travel if the green had been cut to tournament speed.

From the clubhouse nearby that sits majestically on a hill overlooking the course, it was a real thrill to look out on a venue with the feel of a traditional links on the other side of the Atlantic.

This US Open might just prove a classic.

War on dawdlers gathers pace 

Thanks to everyone who emailed regarding last week’s column on slow play. There’s no question this is the most pressing issue to vex the mind of the average golfer, the single most off-putting thing about the modern game.

So, have we seen a real breakthrough at last? What happened over four days at the Shot Clock Masters in Austria was positively eye-opening. 

A low-key European Tour event that normally receives next to no coverage deservedly drew widespread praise all around the world, with No 1 Dustin Johnson leading the resounding applause.

Just look at the startling figures. Thanks to the players being timed on every shot, rounds were reduced by more than 30 minutes over the previous year. In round four, the field was taking less than three and- a-half hours to play 18 holes.

The golf was better too, because the pros didn’t have time to dawdle and second-guess themselves. The scoring average of 72.24 was more than a full shot better than previous editions at the venue in question, Diamond Country Club. The next test, of course, is to make it work at an event where all the top players, who are used to getting their own way, are competing.

But you sense the European Tour’s CEO Keith Pelley has got the bit between his teeth on this one. If the Canadian’s most lasting contribution proves a tour where everyone plays at a pace more respectful of their fellow competitors and the watching public, what a legacy it would be.

item.title: Where were they then? England have named a young and inexperienced squad for the 2018 World Cup... but what were they doing four years ago?
item.description: Gareth Southgate's squad for the 2018 World Cup is one of the most youthful ever selected - only one player has over 50 caps and have an average age of 26. There are few survivors from 2014.
item.content:encoded:
Gareth Southgate's squad for the 2018 World Cup is one of the most youthful ever selected - only one player has over 50 caps and have an average age of 26.

This has some very positive aspects, not least the fact many of the players have not experienced the crushing disappointments of previous tournaments as England players.

In fact, at the 2014 World Cup, only five of the current squad featured, while many were plying their trade in youth teams or the lower leagues.

Here Sportsmail looks at what England's lions for Russia 2018 were doing during Brazil 2014 - and just how far they have come...

 

Trent Alexander-Arnold

Even by the standards of the other players on this list, Alexander-Arnold's rise has been meteoric. In 2014 he was a 15-year-old member of Liverpool's youth team, and was not a regular in the first team until the season just gone.

Jack Butland

Although he made his England debut two years earlier, Butland was very much still a young keeper learning his trade in 2014. He made just three Premier League appearances for Stoke, in between loan spells for Barnsley and Leeds. 

Gary Cahill

The most experienced member of England's 2018 squad with 58 caps, Cahill was first choice for Roy Hodgson in Brazil and played all 270 minutes of action for England - the defeats by Italy and Uruguay and the draw with Costa Rica.

Dele Alli

Now one of England's brightest talents, Alli was an 18-year-old who had just burst into the first team of League One MK Dons in 2014. In February 2015, Tottenham agreed a fee for Alli, and the rest is history.

Fabian Delph

Delph was unlucky to miss out on a place in England's squad for the 2014 World Cup, after making 36 appearances the previous season for Aston Villa. He made his international debut in the September after the 2014 showpiece, but has won only 11 caps so far.


Eric Dier

While England were toiling in South America, Dier was finalising his move to Tottenham from Sporting Lisbon, having played 14 times for the first team in 2013-14 - primarily as a centre back. He goes to Russia as a leading defensive midfielder.

Jordan Henderson

The Liverpool midfielder was another to feature for England at the 2014 World Cup, starting against both Italy and Uruguay. A young buck with just 10 caps then, Henderson is now captain of Liverpool and a leading figure for England.

Phil Jones

Another survivor of the Brazilian debacle, Jones had less blame attached as he only played in one game - the goalless dead rubber with Costa Rica - where he played at right back. Jones is now a possible starter at centre back for Gareth Southgate. 

Harry Kane

In 2017-18, Kane scored 41 goals in 48 games for Tottenham to reassert his status as one of the world's best strikers. It was very different four seasons prior, with Kane making just 19 first-team Spurs appearances and scoring just four goals in 2013-14. 

Jesse Lingard

Now a real contender for the World Cup starting line up after a stellar season with Manchester United, in the summer of 2014 Lingard had just returned to Old Trafford from loan spells in the Championship with Birmingham City and Brighton.

Ruben Loftus-Cheek

In 2014, then 18-year-old Loftus-Cheek was just coming through as one of Chelsea's most promising youth assets, helping the reserve squad to the Premier League 2 title. He hasn't truly cracked the Blues first team, but is on the plane to Russia.

Harry Maguire

Maguire recently shared a picture on social media of him at the 2014 World Cup - as a fan, having travelled to Brazil with his mates. On the pitch, he had just helped League One Sheffield United in a shock run to the FA Cup semi-finals.

Jordan Pickford

Before breaking into the first team at Sunderland, Pickford spent many months out on loan at various lower league clubs. In the summer of 2014, he had just returned from being unable to prevent Carlisle being relegated to League Two. 

Nick Pope

Speaking of keepers whose path to the top was paved with loans - Pope in 2014 played on loan for York City, helping them into the League Two play-offs, where they lost to Fleetwood Town. In 2018, he edged out Joe Hart to make the squad. 

Marcus Rashford

The Manchester United forward was a late pick for Euro 2016 after a breakthrough few months - and he was even further off the radar in 2014. The 16-year-old had just graduated from the United academy, and still had a long way to go. 

Danny Rose

Despite suffering a fractured foot in the first half of 2013-14, Rose was an established first-teamer at Tottenham, with 30 appearances that season. He was therefore unlucky to miss out on Brazil 2014, with Leighton Baines and Luke Shaw picked instead. 

Raheem Sterling 

You all remember where you were in 2014, when Sterling's howitzer after three minutes against Italy in England's World Cup opener looked to have nestled in the top corner, and all seemed right with the world. Sadly, it was not to be. He will once again help to spearhead the Three Lions attack this summer.

John Stones

Stones, then 19, was placed on the 2014 stand-by list by Hodgson, who confirmed he would be drafted in if Jones failed to recover from a shoulder injury. Jones was able to make it and Stones stayed at home, but now gets his big opportunity.

Kieran Trippier

Trippier is now key to Southgate's plan to play with wing backs at the World Cup, but in 2014 he was key to Sean Dyche's Burnley earning promotion to the Premier League, playing 41 Championship games in a successful season.

Jamie Vardy

In his epic journey from Stocksbridge Park Steels to Premier League champion, Vardy in 2014 was celebrating a crucial milestone; like Trippier, he had just been promoted from the Championship after Leicester City won the division.

Kyle Walker

The Tottenham right back was just starting to emerge as a key figure for club and country in 2014, however a groin injury suffered towards the end of the campaign meant Walker had to watch the 2014 tournament on television. 

Danny Welbeck

With 16 goals, Welbeck goes to Russia as the leading scorer in England's squad - but he is no longer first choice, as he was in Brazil. The Arsenal striker started against both Italy and Uruguay but was withdrawn without scoring.

Ashley Young

Before being reinvented as a left back in recent campaigns, Young was viewed as an over-the-hill winger in 2014 (despite being 28). He was left out of the World Cup squad after a disappointing season for Manchester United.

item.title: 'I don't think it would be fair to someone else': Injury-plagued Laura Robson believes she doesn't deserve Wimbledon wildcard
item.description: Ten years on from her startling win in the Wimbledon junior event, Laura Robson has admitted that she feels undeserving of a wildcard into next month's main draw singles.
item.content:encoded:
Ten years on from her startling win in the Wimbledon junior event, Laura Robson has admitted that she feels undeserving of a wildcard into next month's main draw singles.

And even if she happened to be offered one of the precious privileged entries she would be inclined to turn it down.

The 24 year-old left-hander has been hit by more injuries this season and her singles ranking has fallen to 333. It is leading her towards focusing more on doubles play, which sees her on a contrasting upward trajectory and on the cusp of the world's top 100.


'This year, I think even if Wimbledon offered me a main draw wildcard, I wouldn't take it,' said the now British No 9.

'I don't think it would be fair to someone else who could have the opportunity when I have barely played all year. I have been so on and off. The qualifiers, definitely, but main draw, I don't think so. I have had enough chances, don't worry.'

Robson is this week participating in doubles only at Nottingham's Nature Valley Open, having wrestled with a hip problem for several months.

The defining injury of her career, however, was that to her wrist, which required surgery in 2014 and has stopped her fulfilling what looked to be enormous early promise.

It can be easy to forget that Robson collected such major scalps as those of Li Na, Kim Clijsters and Petra Kvitova en route to a peak singles ranking of 27 in 2013 when she was still a teenager.

Being thrust into the spotlight so young by winning Wimbledon at 14 was always likely to be very much a mixed blessing, and so it has proved.

LAURA ROBSON'S RECENT WIMBLEDON SINGLES RECORD

2017 - 1st round

2016 - 1st round

2015 - 1st round

2014 - Absent

2013 - 4th round

'It is probably healthier for me not to think about those early moments at Wimbledon,' she said last week in Surbiton.

'I am where I am now. I love playing tennis, that is what keeps me going. Like other players with injury problems, I believe I am good enough to get back up there. That is why I keep going. I don't want to be at the ranking I am at for the rest of my career.

'Have I thought about packing it in? I think everyone has those thoughts in their job sometimes.

'But I do still love what I do, and I have been doing it for 15 years of my life now. I am not ready to stop yet. I couldn't imagine life without playing tennis - not yet.

'It has been difficult because I have had a hip injury since January. Every time I thought I was getting going it restricted me again.

'So I have been playing doubles, getting some match practice and seeing how my hip goes. Mainly my goal for the coming weeks is to be pain-free.

'You never know how it is going to go. Of course we have seen what Andy Murray's hip injury was like.

'It is never an easy injury and it restricts what you can do in the gym as well. It is definitely one you come out from feeling quite rusty.

'At Surbiton my partner Monique Adamczak and I felt like old ladies in the first match, she had a knee injury and I had my hip injury.'

item.title: Belgium 4-1 Costa Rica: Eden Hazard limps off injured after Dries Mertens, Romelu Lukaku and Michy Batshuayi inflict damage on woeful visitors
item.description: JACK GAUGHAN AT KING BAUDOUIN STADIUM: A slight worry at the end of a stirring night. Hazard suffered a heavy knock, took one look at the Belgium bench and called it quits.
item.content:encoded:
A slight worry at the end of a stirring night. Eden Hazard suffered a heavy knock, took one look at the Belgium bench and called it quits. Just to be on the safe side.

Hazard had truly dazzled, darting and weaving between Costa Rica defenders in a final friendly win before Russia 2018. He looked in slight discomfort when replaced with 20 minutes left, before limping off down the tunnel. It should not detract from a rousing evening that will greatly encourage manager Roberto Martinez.

‘He had a little bit of a dead leg, a little bit of a knock,’ said Martinez. ‘Nothing to be worried about.’  


MATCH FACTS 

Belgium (3-4-3): Courtois; Alderweireld, Boyata (Dendoncker 66), Vertonghen; Meunier (Chadli 46), De Bruyne (Tielemans 71), Carrasco; Mertens (Batshuayi 52), Lukaku (Thorgan Hazard 65), Hazard (Dembele 70)

Subs not used: Mignolet, Ciman, Fellaini, Januzaj, Casteels

Goals: Mertens 31, Lukaku 42, 50, Batshuayi 64

Costa Rica (5-4-1): Navas; Gamboa (Smith 66), Duarte, Acosta, Gonzalez, Oviedo (Calvo 46); Bolanos (Guzman 62), Tejeda, Borges (Azofeifa 76), Ruiz (Campbell 66); Urena (Venegas 46)

Subs not used: Moreira, Colindres, Wallace, Waston, Matarrita, Pemberton

Goals: Ruiz 24

Booked: Gonzalez

Referee: O Hategan (Rou) 

They will not all be Costa Rica, though. They will not all tire so quickly, static and ready to be carved. Belgium, who have Tuesday off, are heading to Russia on a wave of Monday night’s positivity, but will not be fooled by the scoreline.

Martinez will wonder quite how the visitors, who never threatened England going forward last week, were able to take a shock lead via Bryan Ruiz’s scorching volley. And why they were breached persistently until his side really exerted full control.

But then they were far more clinical than England. Martinez will prefer to draw on the goals, the simple majesty of them in front of a crowd fully behind their national team, in stark contrast to the whistles heard here after a draw against Portugal earlier in the month.

He will also draw on the performance of Romelu Lukaku, who now has 13 goals in his last nine international appearances. 

It cannot be coincidence that he thrives under Martinez in a way he has not always at Manchester United.

This was his first brace since February, volleying in Belgium’s second after Dries Mertens had equalised, before powering in a second-half header. Substitute Michy Batshuayi added a fourth after a fabulous team move.

Belgium still need to unlock Kevin De Bruyne’s best, and he is being foiled to a degree by his own manager’s 3-4-3 formation. 

Sitting deeper and evidently frustrated by that, the fulcrum has to also act as an engine if he is to severely impact matches going forward. That does not seem quite fair on him. Equally, it would not be fair if this injury is anything more than a dead leg for Hazard, who felt the full force of Johnny Acosta’s tackle.
item.dc:abstract: JACK GAUGHAN AT KING BAUDOUIN STADIUM: A slight worry at the end of a stirring night. Eden Hazard suffered a heavy knock, took one look at the Belgium bench and called it quits. Just to be on the safe side. Hazard had truly dazzled, darting and weaving between Costa Rica defenders in a final friendly win before Russia. He looked in slight discomfort when replaced with 20 minutes left but not a great deal more before limping off down the tunnel. It should not detract from a rousing evening in Brussels and one, in many ways, to epitomise manager Roberto Martinez. Fearless football, to hell with the consequences, and feeling of unity in flamboyant victory with four goals in the process.

item.title: Vintage Brut, Pocket Dynamo and Main Street among 19 Royal Ascot entries at Goffs London sale
item.description: Two hugely promising two-year-olds and a colt which has staked a claim for the race known as Royal Ascot’s Derby head the horses that will be up for sale at Goffs London sale.
item.content:encoded:
Two hugely promising two-year-olds and a colt which has staked a claim for the race known as Royal Ascot’s Derby head the horses that will be up for sale at Monday’s boutique Goffs London sale in central London.

So far 28 horses, 22 currently in training, are rostered to go under the hammer at the auction staged amid the grandeur of Kensington Palace.

Nineteen of the 22 hold entries at Royal Ascot, giving a would-be purchaser the chance to buy a runner and see it performing in front of the Queen at one of the biggest meetings in the world within days.

The potential royal meeting runners up for sale include Tim Easterby-trained unbeaten Vintage Brut, impressive winner of the Listed National Stakes at Sandown; Robert Cowell’s Pocket Dynamo, who won the Prix Du Cherche Midi at Longchamp on his last run; and John Gosden’s Main Street, runner-up in the Cocked Hat Stakes at Goodwood.

While both two-year-olds are potential runners in the five furlong juvenile races at the royal meeting, Main Street is entered in the Group Two King Edward VII Stakes over a mile and a half.


In four years, the Goffs London Sale has rapidly become established with over £20million being spent on bloodstock.

Around 1,200 invited guests are an audience to some of the world’s biggest bloodstock names battling it out over bids.

Last year Leicester City’s owner Vichai Srivaddhanaprabha spent an eye-watering £2m on seven horses, four of which made it to the starting line at the royal meeting.

No horse bought at the sale has yet won at Royal Ascot but the closest to realising was Cappella Sansevero.

The Irish-trained colt was bought for £1.3m by Qatar Racing in 2014 and finished second in the Coventry Stakes the next day.

Café Society, bought at the sale by a syndicate of Australian racing fans, was third in the Wolferton Handicap at Royal Ascot the same year.

Other big money transactions at the sale include the £1.3 purchase of Irish 1,000 Guineas winner Jet Setting by the China Horse Club in 2016.

Henry Beeby, Goffs Group Chief Executive and the creator of the London sale, believes it has already become an integral part of Royal Ascot week.

Beeby added: ‘In horse racing terms, the London Sale is like being able to buy a Ferrari on the spot, be given the keys and drive it away.

That’s not something that can usually be done with a racehorse.

‘This horse sale is one at which, uniquely in the world, you can buy a horse on a Monday and then watch it race the same week in your own name and in your own silks at the most prestigious Flat racing meeting of all and in front of Her Majesty.’

item.title: 24 Hours of Le Mans: All you need to know
item.description: The 24 Hours of Le Mans endurance race in France will soon get underway. Here's all you need to know about what it is, when and where it is, the entrants, how to watch and more.
item.content:encoded:
One of the world’s most prestigious – and grueling – races is slated to get underway soon.

The iconic 24 Hours of Le Mans race will soon be held, testing the endurance of some of the world’s premier racing vehicles. The difficult race sees dozens of cars compete in a 24-hour endurance event that’s been held annually for almost a century now.

Here’s all you need to know about what the race is, when and where it will be held, the entry list, how to watch, tickets and who won last year.

What is 24 Hours of Le Mans?

24 Hours of Le Mans is the world’s oldest active endurance auto race, first being held back in 1923.

Held in Le Mans, France, the race is among the most prestigious in the world alongside the Monaco Grand Prix and the Indianapolis 500. Often called the ‘Grand Prix of Endurance and Efficiency,’ the race lasts a whole 24 hours and is organized by the Automobile Club de l‘Ouest.

The race tests the ability of competing automobiles to endure 24 hours of sustained performance without suffering any serious mechanical failures. Its prestige and success has inspired a number of other elite races utilizing the 24 hour format, including the 24 Hours of Daytona and Bathurst 24 Hour events.

When is 24 Hours of Le Mans 2018?

24 Hours of Le Mans 2018 will begin on Saturday, June 16 at 9am EST.

Who won 24 Hours of Le Mans 2017?

Team Porsche won 24 Hours of Le Mans 2017, accomplishing the feat in dramatic fashion in spite of serious difficulties encountered during the race.

item.title: Rangers move a step closer to signing Slaven Belupo defender Nikola Katic as club's sporting director insists: 'Everything will be clear very soon'
item.description: EXCLUSIVE: As Sportsmail first reported, Rangers are vying with Spartak Moscow for Katic and Steven Gerrard hopes to pair him with Connor Goldson in a new-look central defence
item.content:encoded:
Rangers moved a step closer to capturing Croatian international defender Nikola Katic on Monday.

As Sportsmail first reported, the Ibrox club are vying with Spartak Moscow for the signature of the 21-year-old and Steven Gerrard hopes to pair Katic with Connor Goldson in a new-look central defence after completing the paperwork on a £3million deal for the Brighton man.

Big-spending Spartak were favourites to out-muscle the Ibrox club for the former under-21 international. However, reports in Croatia claim negotiations with the Russian giants are now in danger of breaking down.


And Rangers hopes of persuading Katic to make the switch to Glasgow have grown following discussions with selling club Slaven Belupo and agent Mladen Kliskinic on Monday.

Slaven Belupo's sporting director Zvonimir Simunovic remained tight-lipped on the Rangers move on Monday night, telling Sportsmail: 'I can't comment about Nikola at the moment, please understand my position. Everything will be clear very soon.' 

Agent Kliskinic was scheduled to fly to Russia for talks with Spartak this morning. And while the Russians have not yet pulled out of the race, Rangers management are cautiously optimistic Katic will become their sixth signing of the summer after Scott Arfield, Allan McGregor Ovie Ejaria, Jamie Murphy and Goldson.

The Brighton defender has completed the formalities of a £3m deal and will join his new team-mates at their pre-season training base in Spain next week after becoming a new father.

item.title: Senegal 2-0 South Korea: Aliou Cisse's men receive timely boost after Moussa Konate's strike seals warm-up win
item.description: Senegal received a World Cup boost by recording a 2-0 victory over South Korea in their final warm-up match on Monday.
item.content:encoded:
Senegal received a World Cup boost by recording a 2-0 victory over South Korea in their final warm-up match on Monday.

Aliou Cisse's side went into the friendly, played behind closed doors in Austria, on the back of a four match winless streak.

South Korea defender Kim Young-gwon deflected an effort by Alfred N'Diaye into his own goal in the 67th minute. 


Striker Moussa Konate added the second from the penalty spot in injury time to give Senegal its first win since beating South Africa in November.   

The African nation are considered one of the earl in Group G where they will take on Poland, Japan and Colombia. 

South Korea, meanwhile, face a tough challenge when they come up against world champions Germany, Sweden and Mexico in Group F.
