item.title: World Cup organisers make final touches to Luzhniki Stadium ahead of Russia's opener against Saudi Arabia
item.description: Russia will get the tournament up and running in Moscow on Thursday, and it seems things are finally falling into place after a monumental preparation period for the hosts.
item.content:encoded:
The final preparations are being made in Russia as the World Cup countdown reaches just four days.

Russia will get the tournament up and running at the Luzhniki Stadium in Moscow on Thursday, and it seems things are finally falling into place after what has been a monumental preparation period for the hosts.

A total of six stadiums have been constructed ahead of the tournament with two more, including the Luzhniki, undergoing redevelopments to make them World Cup-ready.


RUSSIA'S FIXTURES 

Thursday, June 14 at 4pm: Saudi Arabia - Luzhniki Stadium

Tuesday, June 19 at 7pm: Egypt - St Petersburg Stadium

Monday, June 25 at 3pm: Uruguay - Samara Arena

Russia's president Vladimir Putin has manned the mission to present an warmer and more open Russia to the world, and has looked to complete the tournament preparations by sticking to a budget reported to be around £7.4billion. 

With the heavy work finally completed in time, after a number of concerns were raised regarding the preparation schedule, the final touches are now being added to get all host cities and stadiums in shape as the teams and fans arrive in Russia.

Naturally, the Luzhniki Stadium was where the majority of preparations were being finalised ahead Russia's opening group game against Saudi Arabia.

From giant banners and signs to more simple tasks such as the cutting of the grass outside the stadium, it was all hands on deck for the organisers and staff on duty.

A giant 'Russia' sign was erected outside the ground, while staff members were hard at work as they set up a television screen where supporters not lucky enough to get a ticket for the opening game will gather to watch on Thursday.

Russia enter the competition as the lowest ranked team in 70th below their group A opponents Saudi Arabia.

With this in mind they will be looking to get off to a fast start on Thursday night with fixtures against group favourites Uruguay and Egypt to follow.

item.title: McLaren must get their house in order before they leap into IndyCar... with their Formula One struggles, anything else will just be another distraction
item.description: JONATHAN McEVOY: McLaren should not broaden their activities at this point. They are struggling to find form in F1. I do not see how IndyCar could be anything other than a distraction.
item.content:encoded:
The Indianapolis 500 is one of the world’s greatest sports events. The build-up is American razzmatazz at its most extravagant and the race itself is a thrill-a-minute ride on the edge.

So it was an unforgettable privilege to be at the Motor Speedway for the 2017 edition, in which Fernando Alonso excelled. We saluted Zak Brown and co at McLaren's vision in taking themselves across the Atlantic to renew Formula One’s long but broken association with the race.

However, those memories do nothing to assuage my fear that McLaren are badly mistaken in contemplating full-time involvement in IndyCar.


To explore the possibility, Brown traveled to Detroit at the start of the month. He returned to the Montreal paddock to extol the idea in principle, but promised that any move to Indy would not cost the team focus on their avowed priority, namely F1.

My belief is that McLaren should not broaden their racing activities at this point. They are struggling to find form in F1. Their times in qualifying last weekend in Montreal were 0.2sec further behind Renault than in the opening round in Melbourne.

They have not remotely turned around their great team, which is going through the weakest set of results in their history – a malady that has lasted for five years and counting.

I do not see how IndyCar participation could be anything other than a distraction. I accept that they would not share engineers from one series to another, but any thought and time given to IndyCar is of itself an unwelcome intrusion.

For example, Brown’s own energies would be pulled in two directions. How could he give all his attention to F1 while in Detroit? Or Indianapolis, or Phoenix, or Long Beach... 

 

I am happy to report that I escaped without a bloody nose despite Max Verstappen’s response to my question asking why he kept crashing. He said he would headbutt anyone else who asked him about his messy start to the season.

I took his ‘threat’ in good part, though he should note that the questions have stopped not because of what he said, but the way he drove a clean race in Canada to finish third. The remedy lies in his hands rather than in shooting the messenger/questioner. 

 

Winnie Harlow, the model who waved the chequered flag a lap early in Montreal, has been pilloried as if she were a total dunce. She has hit back and quite rightly. The flag marshal told her when to wave the flag and she merely obliged the instruction.

It was fortunate that no fans, believing the race to be over, got on to the track and were knocked over as the cars continued around the circuit at full speed.

Race director Charlie Whiting explained: ‘It was a miscommunication between the start platform and the guy they call the starter here.

'He thought it was the last lap and asked them at the top to confirm it; they confirmed it. They thought he was making a statement when in fact he was asking a question. He told the flag waver to wave the flag a lap early. It was as simple as that. 

'It wasn’t anything to do with the fact it was a celebrity flag waver. The celebrity was not to blame.’

item.title: 'A €200m price tag is nonsense:' Uli Hoeness rubbishes claims that Bayern Munich will sell Robert Lewandowski
item.description: The 29-year-old is regularly linked with a move away from the Allianz Arena and reports have once again claimed Bayern Munich would be willing to cash in for the excessive fee of £176m.
item.content:encoded:
Bayern Munich will not entertain the idea of selling Robert Lewandowski  this summer and have not set an asking price of €200million (£176m) for potential suitors, says president Uli Hoeness.

The 29-year-old is regularly linked with a move away from the Allianz Arena and reports have once again claimed Bayern Munich would be willing to cash in if a club was willing to pay the excessive fee.

But while the German champions would surely have to consider such a mammoth offer if one came in, Hoeness was adamant that no such asking price has been set and says Lewandowski will continue where he is for a fifth campaign.


LEWANDOWSKI AT BAYERN MUNICH 

Joined: July 2014 (free from Borussia Dortmund)

Appearances: 195

Goals: 151

 

Honours

Bundesliga: 2014–15, 2015–16, 2016–17, 2017–18

DFB-Pokal: 2015–16

DFL-Supercup: 2016, 2017

'A €200m price tag is nonsense,' he told Sky Germany.

'Robert will not be sold and will play next season with us. Everything has been said about that.'

Lewandowski has been a key part in Bayern Munich's domination of German football since joining from Borussia Dortmund in 2014 and has scored over 40 goals in three successive campaigns. In total, he boasts 151 goals from just 195 appearances.

His prowess in front of goal has made him a natural target for Real Madrid while the Premier League's biggest clubs, including Manchester United and Chelsea, have also recently been linked.

Lewandowski has won four Bundesliga titles with Bayern Munich, but their last Champions League triumph was in 2013.

It looks as though Lewandowski will stay where he is next season, but for now he will be fully focused on getting as close to a World Cup triumph as possible with Poland.

They failed to qualify in 2010 and 2014, but now find themselves with a good chance of reaching the knockout stages after being grouped alongside Senegal, Colombia and Japan.

Lewandowski, who will captain his country in Russia, kept his shooting boots in good order with a goal in the 2-2 draw with Copa America champions Chile.

item.title: Lionel Messi names his Champions League final header against Manchester United as his best ever goal: 'I don't look at goals for beauty... I look at them for their importance'
item.description: Lionel Messi opted for the 2009 Champions League final header when tasked with picking the very best from dozens of outstanding goals during his glittering career with Barcelona and Argentina.
item.content:encoded:
Lionel Messi rates his Champions League final header against Manchester United in 2009 as the greatest goal of his entire career. 

The five-time Ballon d'Or winner was tasked with picking the very best from dozens of outstanding goals during his career with Barcelona and Argentina. 

His catalogue of brilliance includes remarkable solo goals against Getafe in 2007, Real Madrid in 2011 and Athletic Bilbao in 2015 to name just three. 


But Messi feels a headed effort against Manchester United in the Champions League final in 2009 is the best of his entire career, because of the goal's importance.

'I don't look at goals for their beauty, but their importance,' Messi told Spanish outlet Sport. 'The best goal of my career was the header in the Champions League final, for what that goal and that game meant. 

'I don't have special goals marked out that I'd like to score because for me - the special goals are the important ones.'

Messi's header was Barcelona's second goal in a 2-0 Champions League final win over Manchester United at the Stadio Olimpico in Rome.

With 20 minutes of the contest remaining, Xavi clipped a cross towards the back post and Messi peeled away from his marker Rio Ferdinand. 

The little Argentine seemed to hang in the air as he craned his neck to meet the cross, directing it over Edwin van der Sar and into the top corner.    

Barcelona would go on to win all six competitions they entered that season - Champions League, La Liga, Copa del Rey, Spanish Super Cup, UEFA Super Cup and FIFA Club World Cup - during a trophy-laden spell under Pep Guardiola.  

Messi is currently preparing to lead Argentina at the 2018 World Cup with the weight of a nation's expectations resting firmly on his shoulders in Russia. 

Argentina have been drawn into Group D alongside Nigeria, Croatia and Iceland, who they face in Saturday's opener at Spartak Stadium in Moscow.

item.title: Brazil star Neymar rocks £700 gold bag emblazoned with his family's faces as he lands in Russia ahead of the World Cup... while Paul Pogba dons backpack with his own face on!
item.description: Brazil's golden boy Neymar arrived in Russia on Sunday evening carrying the nation's hopes on his back. But that's not all. He was also showing off his pricey golden backpack.
item.content:encoded:
Brazil's golden boy Neymar arrived in Russia on Sunday evening carrying the nation's hopes on his back.

But that's not all. The Brazilian star was also showing off his personalised £700 gold bag as he stepped off the plane at Sochi International airport.

A drop in the ocean for him in terms of cost, but the bag itself was a one-of-kind flashy accessory with a nod to his loved ones.  


The Nordstrom Rack backpack boasts a silhouette of his family in a touching tribute on the back and is also decorated with golden studs. 

The Paris Saint-Germain star Neymar, 26, has emblazoned an image of his mum, dad, sister and son across it as a reminder of who he is playing for.

France star Paul Pogba opted to rock a similarly outlandish bag as he arrived in Russia for the World Cup, minus the sentiment.

Pogba was seen wearing a French-themed MCM bag with his face and national team number on it as they boarded a bus at the Sheremetyevo international airport.

Like Neymar, Pogba will also be expected to step up to the plate in Russia as a talented France side look to make up for losing the European Championships on home soil two years ago. 

France and Brazil both head into this summer's tournament as heavy favourites but it is the latter who are coming into the World Cup on song. 

Tite's men have consolidated their position as strong contenders in their World Cup dress rehearsals this month.

BRAZIL'S FIXTURES

World Cup 

June 17 - Switzerland - Rostov Arena - 7pm

June 22 - Costa Rica - Saint-Petersburg Stadium - 1pm

June 27 - Serbia - Otkrytiye Arena - 7pm

They eased past Croatia 2-0 before Neymar, Gabriel Jesus and Philippe Coutinho all got on the score sheet as they thumped Austria on Sunday.

The Brazil side is still very much made up of the same players who were part of their 7-1 humiliation at the hands of Germany on home soil four years ago and they will be determined to put that to rest this time around.

Neymar and Co touched down in Russia on Sunday evening and will have a week to prepare for their Group E opener against Switzerland.

item.title: Vinicius Junior left in tears as he bids farewell to Flamengo before joining up with Real Madrid this summer
item.description: Los Blancos' £38million Brazilian prodigy looked visibly upset as he waved goodbye to his boyhood club following their 2-0 win over Parana on Sunday. He will join Real Madrid next month.
item.content:encoded:
Vinicius Junior was left in tears after playing his final match for Flamengo before joining up with Real Madrid this summer.

Los Blancos' £38million Brazilian prodigy looked visibly upset as he waved goodbye to his boyhood club following their 2-0 win over Parana on Sunday. 

The 17-year-old, who will officially join Real on his 18th birthday in July, is widely considered the best prospect to come out of Brazil since Neymar.


It remains to be seen whether he will be sent out on loan again this summer with Real's new manager sure to have some say on that.

Vinicius still does not know where he will spend next season but admitted after the game he expects a decision this week.

'Flamengo is the club that always helped me, took me out of Sao Goncalo and gave me a better life, took care of me. I just have to thank everyone who has helped me since I got to Flamengo,' he said, according to FourFourTwo. 

'It's a difficult moment. I'm where I've always dreamed of. I could be saying goodbye to the greatest fans in the world, alongside my family, friends and everyone present. 

'It's not yet defined [when I will go], but in the next few days it will be and I'll let you know. Flamengo, Real Madrid and my representatives are going to decide.'  

Following the game at the Maracana, Vinicius jumped into the crowd to take some pictures with his adoring supporters.

He then used his shirt as a handkerchief after the occasion seemed to get the better of him.

He has scored six goals and added a further three assists in 15 games for Flamengo in 2018.

Vinicius is becoming synonymous with his electric pace and dazzling technical ability and could become a mainstay in Los Blancos' attack.

The young winger had revealed his ambition to earn a call-up to Brazil's squad for the 2018 World Cup in Russia but he was overlooked by Tite.

item.title: Gerard Deulofeu joins Watford in £15m deal from Barcelona following loan spell at Vicarage Road last season
item.description: La Liga champions Barcelona have agreed a fee with the Hornets of £11.5m plus £3.5m in bonuses for 24-year-old Spanish winger Gerard Deulofeu.
item.content:encoded:
Gerard Deulofeu has joined Watford in a deal worth up to £15million from La Liga champions Barcelona.

Barcelona have agreed a fee with the Hornets of £11.5m plus £3.5m in bonuses for the 24-year-old winger.

The Catalan giants will also receive a percentage of any future transfer moves involving Deulofeu.


On Monday, Watford chief executive Scott Duxbury insisted the move shows the club are constantly striving to improve.

'We are very pleased to welcome Gerard back to Vicarage Road and thank FC Barcelona for their part in concluding this deal,' Duxbury told the club's website.

'Our ambition to succeed and grow in the Premier League remains as strong as ever.' 

Deulofeu, who joined Barcelona at youth level all the way back in 2003, enjoyed a loan spell at Vicarage Road in the second half of last season.

The Spaniard made seven appearances for Watford in the Premier League last season, scoring just once against Chelsea in a 4-1 victory back in February.

Eight years after joining Barcelona as a youngster, he made his reserve team debut in 2011 under Luis Enrique before playing his first game at senior level in August.

Following a frustrating time with Barca, Deulofeu experienced his first taste of Premier League action when he joined Everton on loan in 2013.

Then after a loan spell at the age of 20 to Sevilla under new Arsenal boss Unai Emery, Deulofeu signed a permanent deal with Everton in 2015.

He enjoyed a consistent run of games with the Toffees, playing 37 times before heading over to Italy for another loan spell at AC Milan. 

Deulofeu then joined Barcelona again after impressing on loan at San Siro, playing 17 times under Ernesto Valverde.

However, he yet again failed to nail down a starting spot at the Catalan giants and signed on loan for Watford. 

And after impressing at an inconsistent Watford, Javi Gracia has decided to snap him up on a permanent deal.

item.title: Diego Costa feels the strain as Spain step up preparations for World Cup opener with Portugal
item.description: Atletico Madrid striker Diego Costa looked to be feeling the strain as the striker received medical attention on his right knee during Spain's training session in Krasnodar on Monday morning.
item.content:encoded:
Diego Costa looked to be feeling the strain as the striker received medical attention on his right knee during Spain's training session on Monday morning.

Fortunately for La Furia Roja the issue did not look to be a serious one as the forward was able to complete the session in Krasnodar.

The 2010 champions face their Iberian rivals in Sochi on Friday, hoping to get off to a winning start and make up for their group stage exit four years ago.  


The Spanish played their final warm-up game on Saturday evening, claiming a late victory over England's first opponents Tunisia. 

Iago Aspas came to the rescue of Julen Lopetegui's side with a late strike as they struggled to break down their well organised opponents.

Lopetegui started with nine of the 11 that are likely to line up in Sochi next Friday, arguably the group stage’s most mouth-watering contest.

It completed a mixed warm-up for the World Cup, after a 1-1 draw with Switzerland a week ago.

Spain will be among the favourites when the tournament kicks off in Moscow on Thursday, with hosts Russia entertaining Saudi Arabia.

After taking on Portugal, they face Iran in Kazan on June 20 before finishing their Group B campaign against Morocco in Kaliningrad on June 25.

item.description: US OPEN BETTING GUIDE: World No 1 Dustin Johnson is the bookies' favourite at Shinnecock Hills but the best of the rest are in fine form and lined up just behind him. Here's our top picks.
item.content:encoded:
Rory McIlroy missed his chance at Augusta and Jordan Spieth will have to wait a couple of majors so this week, it's Phil Mickelson's turn to have another tilt at the career grand slam. 

The US Open has been the one that got away from Mickelson - six times he's finished runner-up - and it's hard to see a man who will turn 48 during the tournament finally getting over the line. 

Hard... but not impossible. 

This is the US Open, where strange things can happen. Think back over the past few years where we've had 'putting on broccoli' at Chambers Bay or Dustin Johnson not knowing his score with a few holes to play. That was at Oakmont two years ago when DJ's score was in fact the winning one and he's favourite this week at no better than 10/1. 

Familiar faces are next in the betting and we'll get to them in a bit but what about Mickelson? He's out with McIlroy and Spieth on Thursday and Friday and available at 35/1 (Betfred) or 30/1 with Paddy Power, who, along with Coral are paying out on 10 places.


Since winning the 2013 Open at Muirfield, Lefty's come up miles short in his three runs at trying to become the sixth man to complete the set (he missed last year as his daughter was graduating) but one of his six appearances as a bridesmaid in America's national championship was at Shinnecock in 2004.

He must have nightmares about that one, occupying pole position following birdies at 15 and 16 on the Sunday before three-putting from five feet for double-bogey at 17 and losing by two to Retief Goosen. They were the only two players to finish under par and the average fourth-round score was 78.7 on a day when 27 players failed to break 80. 

We're 14 years down the line and the course has been stretched almost 500 yards to 7,445 but there's a case to be made for Mickelson. He's been back in the winner's enclosure at the WGC-Mexico, has five top-six finishes in 2018 and finished just outside the top 10 in Memphis at the weekend after opening with a 66 and closing with a 65 having played himself out of contention with a 73 on Saturday. Although from California, he's a popular player on the east coast and will be a fan favourite on the far end of Long Island.

At 30/1 and a fifth of the odds for 10 places - there's certainly worse bets. But are there better? At a track like Shinnecock, a proper US Open test, the cream should rise to the top.

DJ hasn't quite been at the same level as he was between Oakmont and August the following year when he was winning for fun but, after recovering from injury he kicked off 2018 with a victory and may have timed this run to perfection with a dominant display to claim the St Jude Classic and take back the world No 1 spot. 

He was widely available at 10/1 to claim a second US Open before Sunday's sizzling 66 but only a couple of firms still offer double figures with most bookies trimming him to 8/1 or 9/1. 

Like Mickelson, Johnson will love the linksy feel of Shinnecock Hills.

The man he replaced at the top of the world rankings, Justin Thomas, will be keeping him company for the first two rounds with Tiger Woods making up one of several showbiz threeballs.

Thomas and Rickie Fowler shot 65s at Shinnecock last year, when it was set up for fun, not a US Open he was quick to point out, and Justin certainly has the iron play to get at the smallish greens. 

He's 14/1 after five top-10s in his last nine events, including his win at the Honda Classic, while McIlroy, with memories of failing big Sunday tests at Augusta and Wentworth still fresh, is the same odds. 

Woods, 20/1 with a couple of firms, has already caused a stir by mooring his $20m yacht in the Hamptons not far from Shinnecock. He's made more than a few waves since returning from the successful fusion surgery on his back but his driving (there were familiar struggles earlier in the year) will need to keep improving for him to have any chance of winning a 15th major 10 years after No 14. 

US OPEN TOP PICKS 

Dustin Johnson 10/1

Rickie Fowler 20/1

Phil Mickelson 35/1 

Martin Kaymer 150/1 

From oddschecker.com - check e/w places with bookies 

BEST OF THE REST 

Dustin Johnson 1st-round leader 16/1

Branden Grace top-10 finish 7/2 

Branden Grace 1st-rnd leader 40/1 

Webb Simpson top-10 finish 6/1

From oddschecker.com - Check e/w places (1st-rnd leader)

His last outing was a T23 at the Memorial which would've been much better if his putter had been working but he said afterwards he was happy with where his game was in his build-up to this one. 

Defending champion Brooks Koepka is around the same price and getting back in the groove having taken a couple of events to shake off the rust after recovering from a wrist injury. This trophy hasn't been retained since Curtis Strange in 1989 but Koepka certainly has the tools to do well while Masters champion Patrick Reed looks a bit big at 40/1.

Elsewhere, Fowler loves the course and at 20s appeals more than 18/1 shot Spieth, who has lost his mojo with the putter. 

Americans hold all the major prizes right now but if that's about to change, Tommy Fleetwood (50/1) and Branden Grace (45/1) could have a big say. And Justin Rose will have plenty of backers too as a run of 20 tournaments since missing the cut at last year's USPGA has brought him four wins, 15 top 10s and 10 consecutive top 10s. There was a time, 2004 to be precise, when he hated this track but now he feels as happy with his ball-striking as he did five years ago - when he won at Merion.

There hasn't been a major winner lower in the world rankings than 48 since 2011 when Darren Clarke (111) and Keegan Bradley (108) upset the odds but if you're looking for a long shot at Shinnecock, how about Martin Kaymer at 125/1. 

He's without a win since this event four years ago but posted his first top-10 of the year at the Italian Open having held the lead at one point.

item.title: Lionel Messi reveals he has no plans to go into management when he retires: 'Right now I don't see myself as a manager... but you never know'
item.description: Lionel Messi is entering the twilight of his playing career but the 30-year-old has not yet made any plans to enter football management as he prepares to lead Argentina at the 2018 World Cup.
item.content:encoded:
Lionel Messi has revealed he has not yet made any plans for a career in management when he retires from football but is refusing to rule anything out.

The five-time Ballon d'Or winner is preparing to lead Argentina at the 2018 World Cup in Russia with Saturday's Group D opener against Iceland fast approaching. 

Russia is likely to be Messi's final chance to win the World Cup while at the peak of his powers - he will be 34 by the start of the 2022 World Cup in Qatar. 


But despite entering the twilight years of his playing career, Messi has not yet made any plans to go into management after he hangs up his boots.

'I haven't thought about it,' Messi told Spanish outlet Sport. 'I don't want to. Everyone lives in their own way - I try to go year after year, calmly. 

'When the day arrives, we will see. I will find the path to follow, I will grab hold of it and we will see how everything goes. Right now I don't see myself as a manager.' 

Former Real Madrid player Zinedine Zidane recently enjoyed a trophy-laden spell as manager of his former team, winning three Champions League titles before announcing his shock departure last month. 

And Messi feels Zidane's situation, who said he'd never become a manager during his playing days, is evidence footballers can't predict what may happen in the future.

'I heard Zidane once say he would never be a manager and after he ended up going into it,' Messi said. 'I don't see myself coaching but I don't know what will happen.'

Diego Maradona, who Messi is regularly compared to in the debate over the greatest footballers of all time, had a two-year spell in charge of the Argentine national team. 

Messi featured under Maradona during Argentina's 2010 World Cup campaign in South Africa as they reached the quarter-finals of the tournament. 

The Barcelona icon reached the final in the 2014 tournament but suffered heartbreak as Argentina were beaten by an extra-time winner from Germany's Mario Goetze.

item.title: Chelsea supporters pose with players as club announce new £10m-a-year sleeve sponsorship deal with Hyundai
item.description: The glossy shot of a player posing in a club shirt - whether as a new signing, to promote a new sponsor or for any reason - has become a staple of modern Premier League football.
item.content:encoded:
Chelsea have secured the most lucrative shirt-sleeve deal in the Premier League after revealing Hyundai as their new £40million sponsor.

And two Chelsea fans got to join their heroes in a photoshoot unveiling the new kit.

The South Korean car manufacturers are spending £10m per season to have their logo printed on the players' sleeves in domestic games, starting from next season.


Chelsea already rake in £40m a year from main shirt sponsors Yokohama Rubber and a further £60m from kit-makers Nike.

But the £40m total from Hyundai outstrips any Premier League rivals when it comes to advertising on shirt sleeves, which was first introduced last summer.

Arsenal recently penned a £30m, three-year deal with Visit Rwanda, while Manchester United are understood to be close to a similar agreement with American kitchen and bathroom firm Kohler.

Chelsea will wear their new shirts, complete with sleeve sponsors, for the first time on July 23 when they face Perth Glory in a friendly in Australia.

While they have their sponsors sorted however, Chelsea are still uncertain about the future of their manager, Antonio Conte.

The Blues have been stuck in limbo as they wait to see whether lawyers acting on behalf of Maurizio Sarri can get him out of his contract stand-off with Napoli. 

As it stands, Conte remains in charge, although his players do not expect him to be there for the start of the 2018-19 season.

It was part of the marketing by Chelsea to announce Japanese car manufacturer Hyundai as one of their new shirt sponsors.

item.title: World Cup 2018: How FIFA plans to tackle racism in Russia
item.description: The 2018 World Cup is due to kick off June 14, 2018 and Fifa's ready to tackle any problems that come their way. The organization's put together a multi-step plan for combating racism.
item.content:encoded:
FIFA is ready for whatever may come their way during the 2018 World Cup in Russia.

The organization has even put together a plan, which official are describing as a 'three-step' process, to combat racism during the month-long event, the BBC reported. 

The process involves stopping, suspending or abandoning games in the event of such occurrences. Their plan was put into effect in response to voiced complaints from players like Danny Rose, who told his family not to even bother travelling to Russia. 

Rose said he was 'numb' to racial epithets and had 'no faith' that FIFA would do anything about it.  

The process will begin with the referees. If they hear racist or discriminatory chanting during matches, they've been told to stop the match and request an announcer ask that the chanting stop.

If the people responsible continue chanting, referees will have the ability to suspend the match, request a second announcement and wait for it to end. 

Per the BBC, should the chanting continue after a second warning referees have been granted that ability to abandon the match entirely. 

FIFA's multi-step process isn't their only response to fears of racism players may encounter in Russia. 

The US didn't qualify for the World Cup, but they're still 2nd in ticket sales pic.twitter.com/gEMy3oA3qT

— Bleacher Report (@BleacherReport) June 8, 2018

They also intend to place three anti-discrimination observers in the stands to keep their eyes and ears out for potential racist acts. 

This system was taken for a test run during the World cup qualifying rounds and the Confederations Cup. 

A spokes person for Kick it Out, an anti-discrimination organization, told the BBC: 'It is imperative that England players follow protocol and report and abuse they suffer to the referee. FIFA must ensure that officials enforce those rules so we don't see players disciplined for reporting discrimination.

'There must be a swift and robust response from the governing body followed by any incident of abuse. Delayed, paltry fines will not be sufficient to foster an environment in which players are protected from discriminatory abuse.' 

What else do you need to know before the 2018 World Cup kicks off? We've got you covered. 

When is the 2018 World Cup?

The 2018 World Cup is due to begin on Thursday, June 14, 2018. The final match will take place on Sunday, July 15, 2018.

BBC and ITV will broadcast the tournament games on TV and online. 

First game of the World Cup 2018

The first match of the 2018 World Cup will take place on Thursday, June 14, 2018 at 11am ET/4pm BST. It'll be a game between Russia and Saudi Arabia. 

That will be the only match that day. 

World Cup schedule printable

You can find the full schedule of World Cup fixtures to download or print in a wall chart here.

Adidas have released their World Cup advert.

🌍🏆 pic.twitter.com/pfqL31w5Su

— Football__Tweet (@Football__Tweet) June 8, 2018

FIFA World Cup tickets 

You can apply for World Cup tickets on FIFA's website. Tickets are still available on sites like Stubhub, but they're going to cost you quite a lot. 

Right now, tickets are going for between $972 (£724) and $14,165 (£10,563). They're also selling out fast.

Find out more information regarding what to do once you've arrived in Russia for the World Cup here.

The player went as far as to tell his family not to even travel to Russia to see him and the rest of the England football team face off in the World Cup. item.title: Two days ago he was watching South Africa beat England as a fan after RETIRING from rugby... now Schalk Brits has been called up to South Africa squad before second Test
item.description: Rassie Erasmus hopes the Saracens great, 37, can use his vast experience and knowledge to aid the likes of Duane Vermeulen and Willie le Roux in helping the Springboks' younger players.
item.content:encoded:
England are destined to face a familiar dangerous foe in Bloemfontein on Saturday after South Africa recalled ex-Saracens hooker Schalk Brits, who retired a fortnight ago.

The 37-year-old finished his club career as part of the Sarries squad who reclaimed the Aviva Premiership title last month. 

His appearance as a replacement in the final against Exeter was supposed to be his final act as a professional player and three days ago he was watching the Springboks win the first Test at Ellis Park as a fan.


However, on Monday Brits was recalled to the squad in the absence of Malcolm Marx and Bismarck du Plessis, South Africa’s leading hookers. 

Now he is in line to win his 11th cap and could find himself in a head-to-head with Jamie George, whom he helped to develop into a Test hooker at Saracens.

‘We’ll definitely consider him for the matchday 23,’ said Boks head coach Rassie Erasmus. 

‘He knows a lot of English players. We can learn from him. But he’s not here just to be a “coach”. You have to remember what a quality player he is. He won the Premiership a couple of weeks ago, so he’s still on the ball.’

Meanwhile, England also called up a hooker, Worcester’s Jack Singleton, as cover for Luke Cowan-Dickie, who has a tight hamstring. 

Singleton was on holiday when he got the call.
item.dc:abstract: South Africa have sprung a big surprise by adding hooker Schalk Brits to their squad ahead of the second Test against England, despite the former Saracens stalwart having retired from rugby at the end of the most recent domestic season. Brits, who recently turned 37, ended his nine-year career with Saracens last month after coming off the bench to help the club regain their Premiership title courtesy of a 27-10 win over Exeter at Twickenham. The former Stormers forward attended the Springboks' impressive 42-39 comeback victory over England in Johannesburg on Saturday as a fan and has now remarkably been called up by director of rugby Rassie Erasmus before the penultimate match of the three-Test series, which takes place at the Toyota Stadium next weekend.

item.title: 'I think Cristiano Ronaldo stays at Real Madrid and Antoine Griezmann stays at Atletico': La Liga president believes two stars will remain at their clubs
item.description: Five-time Ballon d'Or winner Cristiano Ronaldo fuelled talk of an exit from Real Madrid following their third consecutive Champions League triumph in Kiev against Liverpool.
item.content:encoded:
La Liga president Javier Tebas is confident that both Cristiano Ronaldo and Antoine Griezmann will not move on from Madrid this summer.

Five-time Ballon d'Or winner Ronaldo fuelled talk of an exit from Real following their third consecutive Champions League triumph in Kiev against Liverpool.

Ronaldo said: 'In the coming days there will be answer about my future. It has been very nice playing for Real Madrid.'


Meanwhile, Atletico Madrid star Griezmann has once again been heavily linked with a move to La Liga champions Barcelona this summer. 

But La Liga chief Tebas has tried to reassure both Atletico and Real fans that their star players will not leave this summer.  

'I think Cristiano stays at Real Madrid and Antoine Griezmann stays at Atletico,' he told Onda Cero.

Furthermore, Tebas insisted he would be unconcerned if Ronaldo did suddenly move abroad in the transfer window.

'Cristiano Ronaldo leaving, out of 10, I'm worried about a five or a four,' he said.

'It wouldn't be so dramatic for the league. We are becoming more independent of great players.'

item.title: 'I would change some of the trophies I've won with Real Madrid for one big success with Croatia': Luka Modric admits he would trade in his domestic honours for World Cup glory in Russia
item.description: The 32-year-old has won 14 trophies since joining Madrid back in 2012, most recently capturing their third successive Champions League crown by beating Liverpool in Kiev.
item.content:encoded:
Real Madrid midfielder Luka Modric has admitted he would trade in his domestic honours for World Cup glory this summer with Croatia.

The 32-year-old has won 14 trophies since joining Madrid back in 2012, most recently capturing their third successive Champions League crown by beating Liverpool in Kiev.

The La Liga giants did however fail to perform in the league and Spanish cup competition, though Modric believes it was still a successful season. 


'It was a very hard and long season, in La Liga and the Copa del Rey we did not play as is expected of us,' he said speaking at the Croatian Players' Union awards ceremony.

'In the end we won the trophy that is most important. I am happy to be part of this club and this success that will be remembered in history.

'[But] I would change some of the trophies I've won with Madrid for one big success with Croatia!'

Modric, who was named Croatia's player of the year for the sixth time in a row in January, is heading to his third World Cup this summer and remains as integral to his country's chances as ever.

CROATIA'S FIXTURES

World Cup

June 16 - Nigeria - Kaliningrad Stadium - 8pm

June 21 - Argentina - Stadion Nizhny - 7pm

June 26 - Iceland - Rostov Arena - 7pm 

Croatia will again be relying on the midfielder to set the pace and be the creative spark in the middle of the park in Russia.

Zlatko Dalic's men - who lost to Brazil before beating Senegal in their two World Cup dress rehearsals this month - are dark horses for this year's tournament and are tenth favourite with the bookies to go all the way.

A lot is riding on their Group D opener against Nigeria on Saturday with games against Argentina and then Iceland to come after.

item.title: How should England line-up at the World Cup? Our reporters pick their favoured starting XIs for the Three Lions' first match against Tunisia
item.description: England kick-off their World Cup campaign against Tunisia next Monday. But who should Gareth Southgate name in his team? Our reporters have their say on the Three Lions' starting XI
item.content:encoded:
The World Cup is just days away now and belief is slowly growing that England can put recent disappointments behind them and progress far in Russia.

Gareth Southgate has been experimenting with his starting line-up and the best way England should approach their fixtures, starting with the match against Tunisia next Monday.

Ahead of the big kick-off, our reporters pick their favoured England starting XIs.   


 

IAN LADYMAN

(4-3-2-1) Pickford; Walker, Cahill, Maguire, Young; Dier, Henderson; Lingard, Alli, Sterling; Kane

This is a team designed to give England's most attacking players a chance to express themselves. 

England's only chance is if the likes of Sterling and Alli really shine and this team - with two holding players in front of two nuts and bolts central defenders - gives them the opportunity to do that. 

Marcus Rashford is unlucky to miss out but it may be that the Manchester United player is best used as an impact sub anyway. 

JEFF POWELL

(1-2-4-1-2) Butland; Stones; Cahill, Maguire; Alexander-Arnold, Loftus-Cheek, Alli, Young; Sterling; Kane, Welbeck

Butland is still the best keeper and at relegated Stoke played behind a poor defence - essential practice for England!

Stones to be the sweeper behind Cahill, the most experienced centre-back, and Maguire, the best.

It's a worrisome toss-up whoever you pick in midfield but Alexander-Arnold and Loftus-Cheek are high-potential, Alli a risk but little option other than to take it, Young's experience vital on the left.

Sterling, a gifted headless chicken, so might as well let him run loose in the hole.

Kane the first name on the team-sheet as captain and scorer-in-chief but with the rest of the team desperately light on goals Welbeck The Under-rated, with 15 from 37 caps, is the only sane choice for second striker. 

IAN HERBERT

(3-1-4-2) Pickford; Stones, Cahill, Maguire; Henderson; Walker, Alli, Loftus-Cheek, Young; Kane, Rashford

Ruben Loftus-Cheek's sharpness and freshness against Costa Rica puts him ahead of Jesse Lingard, who I originally had as a starter. 

The Costa Rica game also puts Marcus Rashford marginally ahead of Raheem Sterling, though that one's close. 

I'd want Gary Cahill, with his tournament experience and form, in the mix and would have attacking asset Kyle Walker operating further ahead to make room for him.

MATT BARLOW

(3-5-2) Butland; Jones, Stones, Cahill; Walker, Lingard, Dier, Alli, Rose; Sterling, Kane

Balanced, with experience at the back and broad knowledge of a system which accommodates our best wing-backs at wing-back, pace and our most creative players against opponents likely to play with caution.

RIATH AL-SAMARRAI

(3-5-1-1) Pickford; Walker, Stones, Cahill; Trippier, Alli, Henderson, Lingard, Rose; Sterling; Kane

Feels light defensively, so would consider Dier for Lingard for better opposition, but against Tunisia you should go for it. 

They looked decent against Spain but the intention should be to attack, get some momentum for the tournament. Or that's the theory, anyway.

DOMINIC KING

(3-1-4-2) Pickford; Walker, Stones, Cahill; Dier; Trippier, Henderson, Alli, Rose; Sterling, Kane

From the moment England qualified last autumn through to the spring internationals and now the final warm-up games, some of the names have changed but this XI looks primed to open up the World Cup. It has good experience, it is solid and it has goals in it, too.

CRAIG HOPE

(3-4-2-1) Pickford; Walker, Cahill, Maguire; Trippier, Henderson, Alli, Rose; Sterling, Rashford; Kane

Marcus Rashford has played his way into the team and will have a point to prove to the likes of Jose Mourinho of just how he can perform when free of Manchester United's stifling tactics. 

I'd drop Dele Alli deeper alongside Jordan Henderson, who has the experience and calmness to support what could prove a four-man attack when Alli gets forward. 

Kieran Trippier and Danny Rose are perfect for the wide roles, while Gary Cahill can be the bedrock of a three-man defence if flanked by the more expressive Kyle Walker and Harry Maguire. Jamie Vardy needs to be kept in reserve for a Plan B.

JACK GAUGHAN

(3-5-2) Pickford; Jones, Stones, Maguire; Walker, Lingard, Henderson, Alli, Rose; Sterling, Kane

Kyle Walker seems to be the preferred option at centre-half, and is likely to start there, but I'd prefer to utilise his pace and power down the right. 

Plus Phil Jones offers extra defensive solidity. Raheem Sterling's consistency for Manchester City should mean he plays off Harry Kane, while there has to be a place for Jesse Lingard.

Jordan Henderson gives the midfield more aggression than Eric Dier. 

ADAM SHERGOLD

(3-1-4-2) Pickford; Walker, Stones, Cahill; Dier; Trippier, Lingard, Alli, Rose; Sterling, Kane

I'm desperate for England to shed the conservative style of playing that has held them back at previous tournaments, but obviously there has to be a balance to the side.

I think positioning Eric Dier in front of the back three will facilitate the ball playing out of defence that Gareth Southgate is keen on.

His presence would hopefully free Dele Alli and Jesse Lingard to drive forward and do what they do best, while Kieran Trippier and Danny Rose can supply ammunition from wide areas. 

Marcus Rashford and Jamie Vardy are decent impact options off the bench when we inevitably find ourselves goalless with Panama with 20 minutes left... 

KIERAN GILL

(3-5-1-1) Pickford; Walker, Stones, Maguire; Trippier, Lingard, Henderson, Alli, Rose; Sterling; Kane

Jesse Lingard and Dele Alli would be able to step up from the five to join the attack but I like the look of Raheem Sterling behind Harry Kane at the very top. This means no spot for Marcus Rashford but I see him as more of an impact sub.

AMITAI WINEHOUSE

(3-5-2) Pickford; Walker, Stones, Cahill; Trippier, Alli, Henderson, Delph, Rose; Kane, Sterling

Marcus Rashford shone against Costa Rica but Raheem Sterling is the most individually talented player in the England squad. He has to play. 

Fabian Delph worked his way into the side with his display at Elland Road, as did Danny Rose. 

The rest essentially picks itself, although Harry Maguire could displace Gary Cahill over the month.

Ahead of the big kick-off, our reporters pick their favoured England starting XIs.

item.title: Darlington defender Josh Heaton attracting Everton and Middlesbrough interest after impressing in front of Jamie Vardy at the V9 Academy
item.description: The 21-year-old former Preston centre-back was among a number of success stories from the week-long event which looks to give non-League players a chance to impress league scouts.
item.content:encoded:
Everton and Middlesbrough are interested in Darlington defender Josh Heaton following his performances at the V9 Academy.

The 21-year-old centre back, who started out at Preston North End, was among a number of success stories from the week-long event which looks to give non-League players a chance to impress league scouts.

England international Jamie Vardy took a break from his World Cup preparations on Friday to oversee the young hopefuls at Manchester City's training complex which culminated in two showpiece games.


More than 150 scouts turned out and Heaton gave a strong account of himself to impress watching clubs.

Newly-promoted Coventry City also moved to snap up Morgan Williams, an 18-year-old centre back who plays for Evo-Stik Premier League club Mickleover Sports.

Stevenage have also made an offer to 25-year-old striker Cody Cooke from National League South club Truro City.

Cooke scored 13 goals in National League South in 2017-18 as Truro reached the play-offs and also helped the club reach the FA Cup first round for the first time in their history. 

Portsmouth and Exeter City are also keen on Cooke.

However, one youngster who may be spoilt for choice is 17-year-old Sam McCallum from Bostik League South club Herne Bay.

The teenage midfielder, who was rejected by Gillingham as a boy, earned rave reviews and is expected to receive a number of offers.

item.title: Rafael Nadal sported a £540,000 watch as he breezed to his 11th French Open title... one of just 50 of the Richard Mille timepieces ever made
item.description: The Spaniard breezed past Dominic Thiem in straight sets at Roland Garros as he continued his dominance of the French Open with a record 11th success while wearing a £540,000 watch.
item.content:encoded:
Rafael Nadal turned on the style as he clinched his 11th French Open title on Sunday while wearing a rare watch worth £540,000. 

The Spaniard breezed past Dominic Thiem in straight sets at Roland Garros as he continued his dominance of the French Open with a record 11th success. 

During one stretch of the final, Nadal's hand appeared to cramp up and as he received treatment the TV cameras zoomed in on the eye-catching timepiece. 


RICHARD MILLE - RM27-03 WATCH 

Just 50 of the limited edition RM27-03s worn by Rafael Nadal were produced by luxury Swiss watch brand Richard Mille. It was released at the start of the 2018 French Open.

The timepiece featured tourbillon calibre that is capable of withstanding extreme shocks of up to 10,000 Gs. 

The distinct red and yellow of the watch pays homage to the Spanish flag, the country which Nadal hails from.

The RM27-03 was developed in Switzerland following countless hours of testing and includes a distinct amber sheen.

The Richard Mille timepiece is valued at a remarkable £540,000 and is one of just 50 that were produced by the luxury Swiss watch company.

The RM27-03 is just one of a number of flashy watches Nadal has worn during his playing career after sporting an even more expensive model, the RM27-02 at £580,000 during the 2015 French Open. 

Nadal previously told The Wall Street Journal that wearing the watch required a period of adjustment before he felt completely comfortable. 

'In the beginning there was a little bit of transition, we had to work together to adjust everything to my wrist,' Nadal told WSJ. 'It's like you are wearing nothing. It's part of my skin.' 

The 32-year-old later admitted that he was 'very, very scared' when the middle finger of his left hand seized up during the final in Paris.

But Nadal was able to shake off the issue to secure a 6-4, 6-3, 6-2 straight-sets victory over the Austrian that took just two-and-three-quarter hours.

As a result Nadal went three clear of Max Decugis as the most successful French Open champion in history with 11 titles at Roland Garros.

In total Nadal has won 17 Grand Slams during his glittering career - a record which also includes three US Opens, two Wimbledons and one Australian Open.

item.title: Chelsea players want manager situation resolved with Stamford Bridge uncertainty threatening to distract from the World Cup
item.description: Belgium’s Eden Hazard, who himself has held off putting pen to paper on a £300,000-a-week deal with Chelsea, is among those wanting to know what will happen next at Stamford Bridge.
item.content:encoded:
Chelsea's players still expect Antonio Conte will be shown the exit, but are calling for clarity with the club's situation threatening to prove a distraction during the World Cup.

The Blues have been stuck in limbo as they wait to see whether lawyers acting on behalf of Maurizio Sarri can get him out of his contract stand-off with Napoli.

Belgium's Eden Hazard, who himself has held off putting pen to paper on a £300,000-a-week deal with Chelsea, is among those wanting to know what will happen next.


The uncertainty over who will take over as manager is not helping the stars, many of who are set to play a part in Russia this summer.

Two sources close to the club say the squad are still under the impression Conte will leave, but do not know when.

Chelsea have shown serious interest in replacing Conte with Sarri but they did not want to pay £7million in compensation to Napoli. That clause expired at the end of May.

Since then, Sarri's representatives have been trying to get him out of the club, leaving Chelsea waiting for updates.

Former Paris Saint-Germain boss Laurent Blanc and Luis Enrique have also been candidates.

Conte won the FA Cup last season but there was disappointment over his failure to finish in the top four, a year after winning the Premier League title.

item.title: Cristiano Ronaldo leads the way in Portugal training as they continue preparations for mouth-watering World Cup opener against Spain
item.description: The Portugal captain is hoping to add World Cup glory to resume this summer after aiding their march to victory at the European Championships in France two years ago.
item.content:encoded:
Cristiano Ronaldo was on the training pitch early on Monday alongside his Portugal team-mates as they continued their preparations ahead of the start of this summer's World Cup.

The Portugal captain is hoping to add World Cup glory to his CV after aiding their march to victory at the European Championships in France two years ago.

And with only four days to go before Ronaldo leads Portugal out in Sochi for their opening group game against Spain, the Real Madrid star was the epitome of focus at their training base in Kratovo.


The 33-year-old was pictured mostly on his own during the early phases of the session as he calmly juggled the ball, before mingling with some of his team-mates and sharing a joke with one or two.

Ronaldo was pictured laughing and joking alongside his former Real team-mate Pepe, before giving Manchester City's Bernado Silva a quick look at his trademark step-overs.

Portugal arrived in Russia on Sunday and enjoyed their first training session the same day as they look to become accustomed to their new surroundings in Eastern Europe.

They face Spain on June 15, before Morocco in Moscow and then Iran in Saransk on June 25.

And as they look ahead to that mouth-watering group stage opener  - one that should prove crucial in deciding the group's first and second place outcomes - they will hope to have their captain and star man Ronaldo at the peak of his powers.

Ronaldo finished the season well for Real after enduring an uncharacteristically slow start to the campaign where he managed only four La Liga goals before January.

Finishing with 26, however, and 44 in all competitions, Ronaldo has proven that age really is just a number and he is more than capable of delivering the goods in Russia and past the upcoming competition.

He also heads into the tournament with a point to prove. Not just to his employers Real, but also to any potential buyers this summer and in the future.

Ronaldo's place at the Bernabeu has been thrown into doubt after the club rejected his demands for a lucrative new contract that would see him match the wages of Lionel Messi and Neymar.

The seed was planted after Real's Champions League final win over Liverpool in May where he rose questions over his future.

He demanded a wage that would see him become the world's highest paid player once again, but with his current deal to run until 2021 and with a hefty buy-out-clause included, Real feel they are control of the situation.

Reports from Spain at the end of last week had claimed Real have offered him an increase of £6.6million in his annual salary to £28.5m, which would still see him fall short of Messi. 

That has not halted the speculation, however.

A Manchester United return could be on the cards, and so too a move to Paris Saint-Germain with Neymar a top target for Florentino Perez. The Real president has long shown an interest in the Brazilian, who had been linked with a return to Spain for much of the second half of the season. 

Ronaldo will do well not to concern himself with speculation though. He will have his eyes and mind fixed firmly on Portugal's World Cup campaign as he looks to prove he is still worth the value he is demanding.

item.title: 'We've got to do more:' Lewis Hamilton calls on Mercedes to catch Ferrari as Sebastian Vettel takes championship lead with Canadian Grand Pix victory
item.description: Mercedes are playing catch-up but Ferrari will falter, F1 world champion Lewis Hamilton said after German rival Sebastian Vettel won in Canada to take over at the top of the drivers' standings.
item.content:encoded:
Mercedes are playing catch-up but Ferrari will falter, Formula One world champion Lewis Hamilton said after German rival Sebastian Vettel won in Canada on Sunday to take over at the top of the drivers' standings.

Vettel's victory, at a track where Hamilton has dominated in the past but at which he could manage only fifth place this time, left the quadruple world champions a single point apart after seven races.

Mercedes boss Toto Wolff, whose team still lead the constructors' standings, called it a wake-up call but Hamilton made clear that he was already fully aware of the threat.


F1 DRIVERS' STANDINGS
DRIVER TEAM WINS POINTS
1. Sebastian Vettel Ferrari 3 121
2. Lewis Hamilton Mercedes 2 120
3. Valtteri Bottas Mercedes 2 86
4. Daniel Ricciardo Red Bull 0 84
5. Kimi Raikkonen Ferrari 0 68
6. Max Verstappen Red Bull 0 50

'We all know they (Ferrari) have generally had a slightly better package all round, they've been doing a slightly better job so we've got to do more,' the Briton told reporters.

'We've got to keep working, which I know the guys are. And I think we just need to stay positive.

'There's no reason to lose control or anything like that, we just need to keep doing what we're doing and keep our heads down and keep motivated and keep pushing because they will falter. We have to keep applying the pressure.'

Hamilton struggled with engine temperatures during the race, the Briton already up against it with a power unit on its seventh outing against rivals who brought upgrades to the Circuit Gilles Villeneuve. 

Mercedes had planned to have the latest specification on track but delayed it due to quality concerns.

They will need to have that resolved in time for the next race, the French Grand at the Paul Ricard Circuit at Le Castellet next week, a venue that has been off the calendar since 1990 and represents new ground for all the drivers.

'We didn't apply the pressure this weekend, but I'm really going to make sure that we come back strong at the next race,' Hamilton added.

The races are coming thick and fast now, with Austria and Britain on successive weekends after France in a triple-header before Germany and Hungary lead into the August break.

Fans can expect a few more twists and turns before then, and hopefully more exciting fare than the last two served up in Montreal and Monaco.

'We came to Montreal expecting to perform strongly and today's result is a further lesson to us that the historic patterns of performance between the teams are not holding true this year,' Wolff warned.

'It is very hard to see a trend from circuit to circuit, and the race results are being decided by tight margins.

'Which team makes the fewest mistakes, develops its chassis and power unit most effectively, finds the right balance between performance and reliability, and puts together their race weekend cleanly from Friday onwards.'

item.title: England stars fuelled by special tea! Tottenham trio have turned to 'mate' drink loved by Lionel Messi and Luis Suarez as they prepare for World Cup
item.description: The South American favourite, a hit with the likes of Neymar and Lionel Messi, is popular in Argentina and Uruguay and is traditionally consumed through a straw and held in a gourd.
item.content:encoded:
England head to Russia on Tuesday and some of them will be taking some traditional South American tea with them. 

Tottenham trio Eric Dier, Harry Kane and Dele Alli have become fans of caffeine-rich 'mate' tea after manager Mauricio Pochettino introduced them to it.

The South American favourite, a hit with the likes of Neymar, Luis Suarez and Lionel Messi, is particularly popular in Argentina and Uruguay and is traditionally consumed through a straw and held in a gourd.


WHAT IS MATE TEA? 

Mate is a traditional South American caffeine-infused drink that has become particularly popular in Argentina and Uruguay.

It is usually consumed through a straw and held in a gourd.

Spurs and England defender Eric Dier said: 'At Tottenham, quite a lot of us have started drinking this thing called Mate. I am a bit addicted to it!

'We have a lot of Argentinians at the club, so I started drinking it with them.

'And now we are trying to pretend to be South Americans! I haven't introduced it to the boys here at England but me and Danny Rose have a quiet one in our room sometimes.'

Danny Rose added: 'The Spurs boys drink quite a lot and the gaffer — he loves it.

'Me and Eric spend our afternoons playing UNO and sipping tea. I love it, but Eric has to make it for me because I don't know how.'

England kick off their World Cup campaign against Tunisia on June 18.

item.title: World Cup kits - RATED: From England's classic style to the maverick design from Nigeria, your guide to every home and away kit that will be worn in Russia
item.description: Whether you storm to glory or go out early, a World Cup strip can sometimes be the most memorable aspect of a team's tournament. Sportsmail ranks all the 2018 strips here.
item.content:encoded:
Whether you storm to glory or go out before even playing three games, a World Cup strip can sometimes be the most memorable aspect of a team's tournament.

So you can be sure that among the 32 teams that have all released two new kits, there are going to be dashes of brilliance and those of the more forgettable nature.

Sportsmail has gone through the lot and given a rating on the strips you will see this summer... 

 

ARGENTINA

Adidas have arguably the easiest job in football with the Argentina home kit. Blue and white stripes and its good to go. On closer inspection the stripes have a pixelated look to them which surprisingly works well. The away strip borrows another 1990s template and brings what could have been a bland black kit to life. 

HOME KIT VERDICT: 7/10 

AWAY KIT VERDICT: 7/10 


 

AUSTRALIA

Have to admire the folks down under for trying to avoid just releasing a plain gold shirt, but getting a five-year-old to scribble on the sleeves was not the answer. The away kit colours were just about passable but there is no mercy for not committing fully to the sash.

HOME KIT VERDICT: 6/10 

AWAY KIT VERDICT: 5/10 

 

BELGIUM

Even if Belgium were total rubbish at Euro 84, their home strip which is based off their number from that tournament makes it one of the better retro kits on offer this summer. The yellow away strip doesn't quite hit the same notes but there are worse on offer across the World Cup.

HOME KIT VERDICT: 8/10 

AWAY KIT VERDICT: 7/10 

 

BRAZIL

Brazil's World Cup party was going well in 2014 but by advertising it on Facebook they were powerless to stop a load of German footballers gatecrashing and wrecking the place to leave all the locals in tears. They have been in hiding ever since, and their home kit four years later reflects on that with a rather boring strip. The good news is Brazil have probably never had a better away kit - buy this instead. 

HOME KIT VERDICT: 7/10 

AWAY KIT VERDICT: 9/10 

 

COLOMBIA

Colombia were one of the most entertaining teams at the last World Cup kit and at the very least they will look one of the best in Russia. The 1990 throwback for the home strip is well executed, while the blue strip with orange trim will at least mean a Holland away kit will be at the tournament in spirit. 

HOME KIT VERDICT: 8/10

AWAY KIT VERDICT: 8/10 

 

COSTA RICA

One of the surprise packages from Brazil 2014 promise no thrills in Russia judging by their strips on offer. The red home kit is a tidy offering from New Balance with wavy lines stitched in but the white away version just looks like an afterthought. 

HOME KIT VERDICT: 7/10 

AWAY KIT VERDICT: 5/10 

 

CROATIA

One of the early disappointments ahead of the World Cup has been Croatia's World Cup kits. As admirable as it is to try and give the checks a facelift by making them bigger, Nike fall on their sword by not including them anywhere on the back. On this occasion it just looks...odd. The away strip is slightly more attractive but needs more traditional royal blue. 

HOME KIT VERDICT: 6/10 

AWAY KIT VERDICT: 7/10 

 

DENMARK

Look, if it was up to us we would have Denmark playing in that 1986 strip for eternity. Hummel may still be the brand supplying the great Danes, and that's worthy of points on its own. However, their safe approach to both Denmark kits is a little disappointing. 

HOME KIT VERDICT: 7/10

AWAY KIT VERDICT: 7/10

 

EGYPT

You wait 28 years to appear in a World Cup and this is the best adidas can offer you for strips? In 1990s Umbro style, Team Salah could at least have stitched in the Liverpool forward's face wearing a pharaoh's hat in the design of the away kit. 

HOME KIT VERDICT: 5/10 

AWAY KIT VERDICT: 5/10 

 

ENGLAND

After the abomination of England's Euro 2016 strip, anything was going to be an improvement this time around and a long awaited return to white shirts and navy shorts ticks those boxes. The star though is the magnificent red away kit which features a stitched in St George's cross. Hopefully improvements will now follow on the pitch.

HOME KIT VERDICT: 7/10

AWAY KIT VERDICT: 8/10 

 

FRANCE

Quite a lot to admire about the France team, who not only have a squad bursting to the seams with talent but also have a couple of tasty strips worthy of a starring cast. The mixed blue home kit trickles into a tri-colore as it works down to the socks while the white away strip is complimented with light dashes of colour that worked well on England's Euro 2012 kit.

HOME KIT VERDICT: 9/10 

AWAY KIT VERDICT: 8/10 

 

GERMANY

Unpopular opinion time. The retro look from 1990...sorry, it does not work in this case on the home shirt. The seemingly random pattern on the front of the strip was a reference to Germany's World Cup timeline and reversing it simply does not have the same effect. Still looks good though but the away strip stands out more.

HOME KIT VERDICT: 7/10 

AWAY KIT VERDICT: 8/10 

 

ICELAND

Nice try from Errea but if you are going to launch a full colour war on a kit you cannot just stop on the sleeves then go bland on the rest. Iceland's blue home shirt slightly gets away with, but the away white strip doesn't share the same fate. 

HOME KIT VERDICT: 6/10

AWAY KIT VERDICT: 4/10 

 

IRAN

Adidas clearly couldn't be bothered to put a thought of effort into Iran's home kit by giving it a standard template and little else. But at least some life is breathed into the away shirt which features subtle red hoops. Sadly it will probably not be worn in a group where three other teams have a red based home kit.

HOME KIT VERDICT: 6/10 

AWAY KIT VERDICT: 7/10 

 

JAPAN 

It takes a special team to turn up to the World Cup wearing pajamas, and this year Japan are that side. All jokes aside though, this is actually an excellent home kit from the Far East outfit and certainly makes up for the rather dull away strip.

HOME KIT VERDICT: 9/10 

AWAY KIT VERDICT: 5/10 

 

MEXICO

Sympathy for Mexico, especially when they will probably never produce a home kit as good as their World Cup '98 number. This is good enough though and although the away strip is...different, it's not all-white and that's good enough for us. 

HOME KIT VERDICT: 7/10 

AWAY KIT VERDICT: 7/10 

 

MOROCCO

When you have Spain and Portugal to play, you might want to make your World Cup exciting with a couple of memorable strips before a likely group stage exit. Morocco's kits were delayed due to worries over counterfeits and you can see why. Buy a simple adidas shirt stick a Morocco badge on it and you are good to go. The away kit is not much better.

HOME KIT VERDICT: 6/10 

AWAY KIT VERDICT: 6/10 

 

NIGERIA

Teams with lots of history and tradition with regards to their home strip would not get away with what Nike have given Nigeria. But the Super Eagles have a blank canvas as long as green and white feature and what's followed is a World Cup kit to truly remember. Not for everyone's taste but it is a fun strip which is more than can be said for the the poor and bland away kit that I feel sorry for. 

HOME KIT VERDICT: 9/10 

AWAY KIT VERDICT: 6/10 

 

PANAMA

All things being right with the world we can only hope that it is Panama who will wear their away strip when they face Belgium in June. Because it will be a travesty if the away kit, that has audacity to include two chevrons, doesn't get to see the light in Russia of day but the rather forgettable home kit does.

HOME KIT VERDICT: 5/10 

AWAY KIT VERDICT: 8/10 

 

PERU

Brave move from Umbro. Designing a strip for the Kings of the sash was a free pass for not being too inventive. Yet, they gave it a shot anyway by lining it with gold trim. It just about works yet you can't help but feel the away kit is better - and it should not have happened like that. 

HOME KIT VERDICT: 8/10 

AWAY KIT VERDICT: 9/10 

 

POLAND

Certainly no thrills from Poland whose strips for Russia offer nothing to remember them by. Sure, there is a strange diagonal line going down both kits, and this makes them better than some of the other bland kits on offer. Still, though there is better to look at out there. 

HOME KIT VERDICT: 6/10 

AWAY KIT VERDICT: 6/10 

 

PORTUGAL

They may be European champions but when was the last time Portugal actually produced some memorable kits? Well you can add Russia 2018 to the ones to forget pile, although a bonus point is added to the away strip for the only World Cup shirt to feature an algae breakout.

HOME KIT VERDICT: 6/10 

AWAY KIT VERDICT: 6/10 

 

RUSSIA

Long gone are the likes of Roman Pavlyuchenko and Andrei Arshavin so someone is going to have to step up to shine in the rather bland home kit. Alan Dzagoev was good at Euro 2012 wasn't he? Still, the away strip at least looks stylish. 

HOME KIT VERDICT: 6/10 

AWAY KIT VERDICT 7/10 

 

SAUDI ARABIA

Clearly Nike have been spinning too many plates in terms of designing kits for this World Cup. Saudi Arabia's kit was probably thought up in less than two minutes. "Just make an all-white home strip and an all-green away version - oh, and make sure we can see that swoosh stand out on the socks. Next."

HOME KIT VERDICT: 4/10 

AWAY KIT VERDICT: 3/10 

 

SENEGAL

Reverse home and away kits tend to mean bland designs but Senegal slightly rescue that notion with the motif on the the front of their kit -which stands out better on their away green away number. Not the best on offer but far from the worse.

HOME KIT VERDICT: 6/10 

AWAY KIT VERDICT: 7/10 

 

SERBIA

Puma seemed to panic with Serbia's strip. After realising they had basically copied what they had lined up for Switzerland, a last minute decision was made to include the country's flag down the middle of the away shirt. Still, it's better than yet another all-bland all-white kit of which this tournament is saturated with them.

HOME KIT VERDICT: 5/10 

 AWAY KIT VERDICT: 6/10

 

SOUTH KOREA

Those magnificent 1994 World Cup kits are not coming back anytime soon, but Nike could have at least offered something more interesting in terms of a tired looking red home strip. Points are gained though for an away number that carries the design of the national flag on the front. Nice touch, that.

HOME KIT VERDICT: 5/10 

AWAY KIT VERDICT: 8/10 

 

SPAIN

Stuck for a design? Pick a past one instead. That's the template for the Spain home shirt which takes inspiration from the... erm... memorable charge towards the quarter-finals in 1994. The modern twist works well though, which is more than be said of yet another bland all-white away kit.

HOME KIT VERDICT: 8/10 

AWAY KIT VERDICT: 6/10

 

SWEDEN

Sweden have an unfair advantage with kits as they feature the perhaps unbeatable combination of blue and yellow. In truth this doesn't quite mask the home strip being that bland although there is like for the collar that has a nod to World Cup '94 about it. No fear though because the blue away shirt with yellow shorts is a winner.

HOME KIT VERDICT: 7/10 

AWAY KIT VERDICT: 9/10 

 

SWITZERLAND

There really is nothing exciting going on here with Switzerland. Even the home and away kits are the same with reverses in colour. Don't be fooled by the white shorts on the away kit - there are red ones too - although the fear is they could make the kit look worse.

HOME KIT VERDICT: 6/10 

AWAY KIT VERDICT: 6/10 

 

TUNISIA

Some of the other low ranked sides in the tournament have an excuse for being shunned in terms of designs due to their manufacturer having focus elsewhere. But what's Tunisia's? Two kits from Uhlsport that are entirely forgettable unless the England circus turns up with a performance enough to top the clowns from against Iceland during Euro 2016. 

HOME KIT VERDICT: 6/10 

AWAY KIT VERDICT: 6/10 

 

URUGUAY

No surprises from Uruguay, who will turn up in Russia with their unique sky blue shirts, black shorts and socks combination. Still, with a stitched in sun on the front it looks good. The white away strip? Just bland, although there is a blue shorts version available which might just save it. Either way you can be sure Luis Suarez will bite your arm off to wear these in Russia.

HOME KIT VERDICT: 8/10 

AWAY KIT VERDICT: 6/10
item.dc:abstract: Whether you storm to glory or go out before even playing three games, a World Cup strip can sometimes be the most memorable aspect of a team's tournament. So you can be sure that among the 32 teams that have all released two new kits, there are going to be dashes of brilliance and those of the more forgettable nature. Sportsmail has gone through the lot and given a rating on the strips you will see this summer...

item.title: 'We need as many teams competing at the top end as possible': Nico Rosberg on making F1 more exciting, Daniel Ricciardo to Mercedes rumours and his new drink-driving campaign
item.description: EXCLUSIVE INTERVIEW BY MATTHEW SMITH: Canada was the latest race to attract criticism for a lack of action, and Rosberg feels that more teams battling for victory is the most viable tonic.
item.content:encoded:
The Canadian Grand Prix was the latest F1 race to attract criticism for a lack of action, and Nico Rosberg feels that having more teams in a position to battle for victory stands as the most viable tonic.

Rosberg, who retired four days after winning his maiden F1 championship in 2016, has remained involved in the sport as a television pundit and commentator.

It means he has had a first-hand view of a 2018 season where, despite there being three different winners in the first seven racers and only one point separating Lewis Hamilton and leader Sebastian Vettel in the drivers' standings, the grands prix themselves have yet to truly capture the imagination.

Scroll down for video 


Montreal was a case in point, with only Brendon Hartley's spectacular first-lap crash enlivening a procession which Vettel led from start to finish.

Rosberg, speaking as an ambassador for Heineken's 'When You Drive, Never Drink' campaign, said while he remains entertained by his old sport, having more teams challenging front runners Mercedes and Ferrari would be a major boost.

He said: 'Yes, I love watching F1 as a spectator. I would say this is a great position for us to be in at this point in the year.

'For F1 to be more exciting we need as many teams competing at the top end as possible, with Red Bull doing better this year that has added another element to the races.

'The other thing that would make F1 more exciting is more overtaking, however, there is no easy way to make this happen and it has been an issue for years now.'

Rosberg feels there is a three-driver competition for the title this season, and backed Red Bull racer Daniel Ricciardo to close the gap to Hamilton in his Mercedes and Ferrari's Vettel.

He said: 'We definitely have more legitimate competitors at this stage for the title than in previous years.

'Daniel was very unlucky in two races this year, so he has some catching up to do, but he has proven from the Monaco victory that he can win even if the car is under-performing.

'It’s great to have all three of them driving so well, therefore from race to race it is hard to predict who will win.'

Despite this, Rosberg refused to comment on constant rumours that Ricciardo could replace Valtteri Bottas - who came in at Mercedes when the German quit the sport.

Ricciardo is in high demand with his Red Bull contract set to expire at the end of the season, while Bottas - who is still yet to completely convince with no wins in 2018 - is also reach the end of his deal.

However, Rosberg said: 'It is not fair for me to give an answer to this question. I think either of them would do a great job at Mercedes next year, there are a lot of drivers who have not signed contracts yet for 2019, so it will be very intriguing to see what happens in the next few months on who goes where.'

Rosberg is fronting Heineken's new 'No Compromises' series of adverts, which is aiming to change the attitude of drink drivers, with prompts and reminders placed in 10 UK bars as part of a psychological pilot scheme.

He said: 'Both on the track and on a night out, people should stick to their intentions – just like I wouldn’t compromise the position of my car in a race, I also wouldn’t give in to having a beer with friends if it compromised their safety.

'We are sending a clear message – when you’re behind the wheel, abstinence is the only option.'

item.title: Benjamin Mendy and Kylian Mbappe discover brilliant portraits painted on their hotel doors as France stars arrive in Russia ahead of the World Cup
item.description: Finding your hotel room in a huge resort can be tricky, but the France squad had no such problems upon arriving at their Moscow base ahead of the World Cup.
item.content:encoded:
Finding your hotel room in a huge resort can be tricky, but the France squad had no such problems upon arriving at their Moscow base ahead of the World Cup.

The Hilton Garden Inn on the outskirts of Russia's capital is playing hosts to Les Bleus throughout the tournament and their owners pulled out all the stops to make sure the likes of Kylian Mbappe and Benjamin Mendy felt as special as possible.

Making their way through the corridors, players quickly noticed that the Hilton had ditched their room number system and painted individual portraits on the front doors for each of the 23-man squad.


Mendy, who posted a video of the players making this discovery, also revealed that more murals had been painted on the inside of their rooms. With defender Adil Rami looking particularly ecstatic, the Hilton achieved their mission of making the players feel like celebrities.

But the VIP treatment didn't stop there. Mendy also revealed that the hotel had personalised Russian dolls made for each of the players and placed inside their rooms.

For many of the France squad, including Mendy, Mbappe and Ousmane Dembele, the World Cup in Russia will be their first major international tournament. With an average age of just 26, Didier Deschamps' squad is the third youngest competing in Russia behind only England and Nigeria.

But despite their lack of experience, the formidable talent on offer makes them one of the favourites to win the World Cup. Most bookmakers place them behind only Brazil and holders Germany with average odds of around 6/1.

Their task of winning a second world title would be made much easier if Paul Pogba could find his best form. The midfielder is the undoubted star of the team but has struggled to perform at his best in recent months.

There have been calls for him to be dropped, but Deschamps is ready to ignore the critics and start Pogba in their opening group game against Australia on Saturday.

He said: 'I defended him after the match in Nice against Italy,' Deschamps said. 'He was much better against the USA.

'There are very high expectations for him. It's normal, and when he does things well, he always has to do better. But, with all that Paul is able to do, it's always about the team. That is what's important to me.'
