item.title: Mohamed Salah asks fan to get off his injured left shoulder after Egypt supporter embraced him as he departed their team bus
item.description: The Pharoahs' talisman was set upon by a fan as he departed Egypt's team bus with the supporter taking his phone out to request a selfie but had to ask him to remove his arm from the injured shoulder.
item.content:encoded:
Mohamed Salah gave an indication into his injury recovery on Monday when he was forced to instruct an overeager Egypt supporter to get off his left shoulder. 

The Pharoahs' talisman was set upon by a fan as he departed Egypt's team bus with the supporter taking his phone out to request a selfie. 

In the process, the supporter embraced Salah and placed his hand on his shoulder, before the Liverpool star sought evasive action as he appeared in discomfort. 

This fan forgot about Salah's shoulder injury! pic.twitter.com/jTFyLw5PPk

— golazolive (@golaz0live) June 10, 2018

A security guard promptly intervened and escorted Salah safely past the supporters gathered by the team bus and into a nearby facility.  

The hopes of the north African nation are resting on Salah's shoulders with the start of Egypt's World Cup campaign now just four days away.

Salah faces a battle to be fit in time for Friday's opener against Uruguay as he attempts to recover from the injury he sustained while playing for Liverpool in the Champions League final. 

Egypt's official line is that they are hopeful Salah will be available but coach Hector Cuper insisted his side must learn not to depend on the forward. 

'It's difficult to find anyone who can replace Salah,' Cuper said. 'But we have a substitute plan, because the team cannot depend on just one player.' 

Salah revealed last week that Real Madrid's Sergio Ramos sent him a message to apologise for the challenge that resulted in the shoulder injury. 

The 25-year-old had left the Kiev pitch in tears after the incident as he realised his World Cup hopes had been placed in jeopardy by Ramos' cynical challenge.

And Salah suggested he was not yet ready to forgive the Madrid skipper and has not accepted Ramos' apology in an interview with Spanish outlet Marca. 

'It was (the worst moment of my career),' Salah told Marca. 'When I fell to the ground, I had a mixture of physical pain and a lot of worry. Also anger and sadness for not being able to continue playing the Champions League final.

'Moments later, I also thought about the possibility of not playing in the World Cup and that was a devastating thought. He sent me a message, but I never told him it was OK.'

item.title: Man United's new £17.4m signing Diogo Dalot pictured on crutches as he recovers from the knee injury that curtailed his season with Porto
item.description: Manchester United's new signing Diogo Dalot will be using his first few weeks at the club to recover from knee surgery. The £17.4m signing was pictured on crutches at the Soccer Aid match at Old Trafford
item.content:encoded:
Manchester United's new signing Diogo Dalot will be using his first few weeks at the club to recover from knee surgery.

The 19-year-old, who completed his £17.4million move from Porto last week, was walking with the aid of crutches as he attended the Soccer Aid match at Old Trafford on Sunday night.

Dalot took the time to sign autographs for supporters as he explored his new home, but he does face a race to be fit for United's pre-season tour of the United States.


The meniscus injury ruled Dalot out of the last three matches of Porto's season and he is unlikely to be fully fit when he makes permanent his move to Manchester later this month.

United expect Dalot to be ready to resume training in time for their pre-season tour, which sees them play five times in five different locations within two weeks.

The first of these is against Club America in the Phoenix Stadium, Arizona on July 19.

From there, Jose Mourinho's squad travel to Santa Clara to take on Major League Soccer side San Jose Earthquakes on July 22.

Man United pre-season tour 

July 19 Club America (Phoenix Stadium, Arizona; 3am UK time on July 20)

July 22 San Jose Earthquakes (Levi's Stadium, Santa Clara; midnight UK time on July 23)

July 25 Milan (Pasadena Rose Bowl, California; 4am UK time on July 26)

July 28 Liverpool (Michigan Stadium, Ann Arbor; 10pm UK time)

July 31 Real Madrid (Hard Rock Stadium, Miami; 1am UK time on August 1) 

United will then play three matches in the International Champions Cup - against Milan in Pasadena on July 25, Liverpool in Michigan on July 28 and Real Madrid in Miami on July 31.

Speaking shortly before he completed his move to United, Dalot told Radio Renascenca: 'The recovery is going well. Above all, it takes a lot of patience, knowing that it's a lengthy process and without hurry to achieve maximum recovery.

'It's for it to be at the highest level I work. The priority is to recover well from the knee so I continue to evolve.'

Another new United signing, the Brazilian midfielder Fred, suffered an ankle injury in training but is still set to take part in the World Cup.

item.title: Real Madrid monitoring Jan Oblak, Thibaut Courtois and Alisson as they look for No 1 to replace Keylor Navas
item.description: Despite helping Spanish giants Real Madrid win a remarkable three Champions League in a row, current No 1 Keylor Navas has failed to convince the club's hierarchy.
item.content:encoded:
Real Madrid are keeping a close eye on Thibaut Courtois, Jan Oblak and Alisson, according to reports in Spain.

Despite helping Madrid win a remarkable three Champions League in a row, current No 1 Keylor Navas has failed to convince the club's hierarchy.

And according to Spanish publication AS, the European giants have three shot-stoppers in mind to replace the Costa Rica international this summer.


Chelsea goalkeeper Courtois has been a long-term target for Madrid and has yet to sign a new deal at Stamford Bridge with his current terms expiring in 2019.

Atletico Madrid star Oblak, who played an influential role in them winning last season's Europa League, is tied to the club until 2021 and has a release clause of £87million.

Meanwhile, Roma No 1 Alisson, who helped his side reach the Champions League semi-finals, is also contracted until 2021 and would cost in the region of £70m.

Despite having no manager in place following Zinedine Zidane's shock resignation, Madrid are still hot in their pursuit of their top summer transfer targets. 

President Florentino Perez is desperate for Madrid to compete with La Liga champions Barcelona next season, after the Catalan giants finished 17 points ahead.

item.title: Wolves closing in on loan deal for Mexico forward Raul Jimenez
item.description: Wolves are expected to pay an initial £3m loan fee for Raul Jimenez. The Benfica forward rated at £34million by his club and was considered by Everton last year.
item.content:encoded:
Wolves are closing on a loan deal for Mexico striker Raul Jimenez.

The Benfica forward is rated at £34million by his club and was considered by Everton last year.

Wolves are expected to pay an initial £3m loan fee for a forward who scored eight goals last season.


Meanwhile, Wolves are among the clubs showing interest in Florin Nita of Sparta Prague.  

The 30-year-old goalkeeper is seen as an alternative to Rui Patricio of Sporting Lisbon.

Nita, a Romania international, could be available on an initial loan with view to a £4.5m transfer at the end of the season and has interest from other Premier League sides.

Wolves have been in negotiations over Rui Patricio but the deal stalled after a dispute between Sporting and his agents Gestifute.

item.title: PSG step up chase for N'Golo Kante as sporting director Antero Henrique 'meets with agent in London and Paris'
item.description: According to Paris United, Thomas Tuchel's PSG are looking to strengthen their midfield for a Champions League run after also meeting with the entourage of Julian Weigl in April.
item.content:encoded:
Paris Saint-Germain are continuing their long-running pursuit of N'Golo Kante, with the latest reports suggesting that sporting director Antero Henrique has met with the Chelsea midfielder's agent in London and Paris over recent weeks in order to discover his future intentions.

That is according to Paris United, who claim Kante's official representative - Karim Douis - and part of his entourage are keen for him to sign for PSG and that the former Boulogne and Caen man, also on the radar of reigning European champions Real Madrid, is no longer completely dismissive of a potential return to his native France.

The report goes on to state that Chelsea, looking to restructure their midfield as they keep an eye on the likes of Amiens' Tanguy Ndombele, Napoli's Amadou Diawara and Jean Michael Seri of Nice, would look to receive around €80million (£70.3million) for a player they signed from Leicester City in a £30m deal back in July 2016.


Prominent agent Pini Zahavi, who was involved in Neymar's world-record move to the Parc des Princes from Barcelona last year, is said to have a key role in any potential deal, particularly in terms of sourcing an adequate replacement for Chelsea. 

Links between PSG, also pursuing Julian Weigl following the appointment of former Borussia Dortmund boss Thomas Tuchel, and Kante are certainly nothing new and last month the 27-year-old insisted he had not received any approaches from interested parties while reiterating that he was only focused on the World Cup in Russia.

However, it has been claimed that many of Chelsea's FA Cup-winning stars have become concerned by the delay in tying down a replacement for Antonio Conte, who is still expected to leave Stamford Bridge this summer following a woeful defence of the title he claimed in his maiden season at the helm.

Just as he was during Leicester's shock title success in 2016 with his sheer energy, incredible work rate, tackling prowess and combativeness, Kante was a crucial figure in that Chelsea triumph and subsequently received several high-profile individual honours including the PFA Player of the Year award.

He has made a total of 89 appearances across all competitions for the Blues in two seasons, including 48 last term as they not only failed to defend their crown but also missed out on a place in the top four. 

Kante will be a key cog of France's star-studded midfield as they aim to banish memories of their painful Euro 2016 final defeat on home soil and Les Bleus head coach Didier Deschamps reportedly made it expressly clear that he wanted all transfer business involving his players to be completed by the weekend before the tournament gets underway.

Following a somewhat disappointing final warm-up friendly draw against the United States in Lyon at the weekend, a game in which Kante featured for the full 90 minutes, France flew into Moscow's Sheremetyevo International Airport on Sunday before arriving at their World Cup base at the Hilton Garden Inn, New Riga.

Deschamps' side open their Group C campaign against Australia in Kazan on Saturday before facing Peru in Yekaterinburg and Denmark in Moscow.

item.title: England face a long road to World Cup glory with over NINE THOUSAND miles on the clock to reach the Moscow final... the same distance from the UK to Australia! But which side will travel the furthest?
item.description: Never before has England's road to a World Cup final seemed so long and this time it is not just because of a squad that appears to be lacking compared to rivals.
item.content:encoded:
Never before has England's road to a World Cup final seemed so long and this time it is not just because of a squad that appears to be lacking compared to rivals.

That's because if Gareth Southgate's men are to emerge triumphant in Russia this summer they may have to travel the distance from England to Australia to land a first major tournament success in 52 years.

The Three Lions are based north west of Saint Petersburg throughout a group stage where they will be travelling more than many other teams during the tournament.


But should England reach the final at the Luzhniki Stadium in Moscow they could have travelled over 9,300 miles.

This factors in that they remain at their Forrest Mix Sport & Relax team base camp throughout the entire tournament and also includes their initial flight from England.

Southgate's team will be playing in Volgograd, Nizhny Novgorod and Kaliningrad during the group stage, but their route to the final could be shorter if they finish runners-up in Group G.

ENGLAND'S ROUTE TO THE WORLD CUP FINAL

Heathrow to St Petersburg 1307 miles

GROUP STAGE 

vs Tunisia (Volgograd) 1964 miles

vs Panama (Nizhny Novgorod) 1151 miles

vs Belgium (Kaliningrad) 1025 miles

KNOCK OUT PHASE (group winners) 

Last-16 (Rostov) 1961 miles

Quarter-finals (Kazan) - 1529 miles

Semi-finals (St Petersburg) - 36 miles

Final (Moscow) 416 miles

OR 

KNOCK OUT PHASE (runners-up)

Last-16 (Moscow) 833 miles

Quarter-finals (Samara) - 1805 miles

Semi-finals (Moscow) - 833 miles

Final (Moscow) 416 miles (one way)

 

Total: 9,389 miles (group winners)

or 9,317 miles (group runners-up)

Providing they stay near Saint Petersburg, the route to the Moscow final would see three of their four knock-out matches take place in the Russian capital, with just a trip to Samara in the quarter-finals.

This works out around 62 miles (100km) less than winning Group G where they instead would compete in Rostov, Kazan and Saint Petersburg before reaching the Luzhniki Stadium.

During the group stage of the tournament all teams will stay and train between matches at their base camps.

It is from here they will then travel to the venues of their respective games, where they will stay overnight at a local hotel and have the opportunity to train at a nearby site.

In principle, all teams should stay in the local hotel at nights before and after the match in question.

Heading into the last-16 and beyond, teams have the option to remain at their base camps or to move from city to city depending on the location of their matches. 

England will have to put in more miles than most other teams - including all their group rivals - during the group stage of the tournament at least, but it is Egypt who will have to do the most. 

There is no rest in Mohamed Salah's busy schedule following the Champions League final. 

Even if Egypt fail to get past the group stage in Russia, the Liverpool forward will still travel more than 5,600 miles in the group stage alone, with games in Ekaterinburg, Saint Petersburg and Volgograd.

Salah's Anfield team-mate Roberto Firmino will also be on the move as his Brazil side are one of nine teams who will travel further than England during the early stages of the tournament. 

The big winners though appear to be Colombia who face a very short distance in travelling just 750 miles. Their commute across the three matches is less than half of the second least-travelled team in Argentina.

Hosts Russia also have a more settled travel schedule, ranking fifth lowest while world champions Germany will be happy to creep into the top 10.
item.dc:abstract: Never before has England's road to a World Cup final seemed so long and this time it is not just because of a squad that appears to be lacking compared to rivals. That's because if Gareth Southgate's men wish to emerge triumphant in Russia this summer they may have to travel the distance from England to Australia to land a first major tournament success in 52 years. The Three Lions are based north west of Saint Petersburg throughout a group stage where they will be travelling more than many other teams during the tournament.

item.title: Tiger Woods has not won a major for 10 years and Jack Nicklaus's record total now looks unbeatable... so why do we even care about him any more?
item.description: That heroic victory at Torrey Pines, 10 years ago now, took its toll. It was Tiger Woods's last major win and after it became apparent that He was human after all. Once, we thought he might not be.
item.content:encoded:
For so long it was a question of when, not if.

He had arrived even before most of the world had ever seen Him hit a ball, with Nike lighting the fuse by filming an ethnically diverse succession of children proclaiming 'I am Tiger Woods'. An explosive 12-shot win at the Masters aged just 21 then followed and it was clear: this would be the greatest golfer the world had ever seen.

In the years after his 1997 win at Augusta came even more extraordinary feats: a 15-shot winning margin in the US Open at Pebble Beach, the most destructive performance of all time; back-to-back triumphs at St Andrews; the career Grand Slam and then holding all four major titles at once - the 'Tiger Slam'; and winning the US Open on one leg, having played four rounds on a left tibia fractured in two places and with the ligaments in his left knee all but destroyed. That took Him within four majors of Jack Nicklaus's all-time record of 18, and still only at the age of 32.

But then it became a question of if, not when.

That heroic victory at Torrey Pines took its toll, leading to serious knee surgery. Back problems started to follow and, with each debilitating injury and subsequent operation it became apparent that He was human after all.


An addiction to powerlifting in the gym and brutal training with Navy Seals - an obsession sparked by his adoration for his Green-Beret father, Earl, according to his former coach Hank Haney – had left his body broken and patched together by surgeons.

There was no surgery possible to save his marriage, however. The evening when it emerged that Woods, then the most high-profile sportsman in the world, had been 'seriously hurt' in a car accident sparked a frenzy of speculation and grave concern: What happened? What were his injuries? What does it mean for his playing career? Will he ever be the same again? Thankfully, his injuries turned out not to be as bad as first feared; but his life, and his career, were never the same again.

The events of November 27, 2009 were more extraordinary than anyone had possibly imagined: at around 2.30am Woods had crashed his Cadillac Escalade SUV into a tree and fire hydrant near his home in Florida; he had been woken by his wife, Elin, after she had discovered text messages on his phone from another woman – a mistress; Elin had accused Woods of adultery and he fled, half-conscious due to the sleeping pills he had taken earlier; unfit to drive, he crashed; Elin chased after and attacked the car with, reportedly, a 9-iron.

The days that followed revealed Woods to be a serial cheater, with a bewildering array of waitresses, hostesses and porn stars claiming to have slept with him. In a matter of days, Woods's reputation degenerated from saintly to sleazy.

He has not won a major championship since. 

 

The sleaze scandal is, sadly, seemingly destined to be Woods's legacy among much of the public, who are, it must be said, not golf fans and so couldn't care less whether he wears a green jacket, red shirt or a yellow polka-dot bikini.

It is hard to imagine now, given the past decade of playing decline and personal fall, just what fevered excitement Woods once generated. His domination over golf was absolute; his name and face were ubiquitous. The world and his mother knew all about Tiger Woods.

Woods spent 683 weeks ranked as the world's No 1 golfer – that's more than 13 years. In his prime he hit the ball further than any other player, he had more control and creativity with his irons than anyone, he had the best short game and his putting was, you guessed it, the best again. No-one has been able to hole as many crucial putts at the time when they were needed most; no-one has matched his mental fortitude or exhibited such a relentless thirst for victory; no-one has emitted such guttural roars or fist pumps that threatened to wrench an arm from its socket like he has.

The staggering lists of records he has set speak for themselves. As well as those combined 13 cumulative years as world No 1, Woods has won 79 PGA Tour events among 106 professional wins worldwide, including eight wins in a single year three times. In late 2006 and early 2007, he won seven consecutive tournaments, more than most top-level players manage in an entire career. In 2013, perhaps the only season post-scandal that he has been fully fit, he won five times.

More importantly, Woods is the only player ever to have won all four of the modern major championships consecutively – the famous Tiger Slam. He is the fifth and to date most recent player to complete the career Grand Slam of winning all four majors. Just ask Rory McIlroy, now aged 29 and struggling so desperately to get over the line at the Masters and join golf's most elite group. Tiger did it aged just 24 - and he has done it three times over, something only Nicklaus can match.

At the age of 32, Woods was well on course to beat Nicklaus's major record, having won his 14th three years earlier than the Golden Bear had reached that number. Nicklaus also took until he was 46 to win his final Masters in 1986 - after the 2008 US Open, Woods had a full 14 years to catch him.

Beyond the wins there are more extraordinary feats and statistics. His scoring average during the year 2000 was the lowest in history: 68.17. In effect, that means every time he teed it up Woods averaged what would be a score of 4 under par on a par-72 course. Take a look at the 10 lowest season-scoring averages in tour history and the four lowest are by Woods, as are six of the top eight. He once went through a streak of 66 competitive rounds where he shot even par or better.

Between February 1998 and May 2005 he did not miss a single cut, setting a record streak of 142 tournaments. The next best records belong to Byron Nelson and Nicklaus, who made 113 and 105 straight cuts respectively. And to put that into further context, the best active streak of cuts made on the PGA Tour is by Adam Hadwin, who has made 19 straight – just the 123 behind Woods's record.

But it was not the numbers alone that enshrined Woods as a golfing divinity. When not playing well, he found ways to dig deep and win, even against the best the world had to offer. But when he was on form he simply crushed them.

That first Masters win saw him set the lowest score relative to par of all time at Augusta, at 18 under (Jordan Spieth matched this score in 2015.) That utter demolition at Pebble Beach saw him become the first player to finish double-digits under par in a US Open – and no other player in that field even broke par (this also happened at the 2002 US Open at Bethpage Black). Fifteen strokes remains the greatest single winning margin in any major, but he also won The Open by a record eight strokes, at St Andrews in 2000. When he won the 2006 US PGA Championship at Medinah, Woods became the only golfer to have won all four majors by at least five strokes.

Any efforts to put Woods off his stride were met with something near contempt. Woods set out to eviscerate anyone who tried to knock him off his perch. Colin Montgomerie was the first to try at the Masters in 1997, suggesting his rival would be too young to cope with the pressure of leading. By the end, it was Monty who was the gibbering wreck. And pity poor Stephen Ames, an opponent at the 2006 Match Play Championship, who boldly suggested that 'anything can happen, especially where he's hitting the ball.' Tiger won the match 9&8.

Perhaps the most demonstrable measure of his dominance, however, was in the coining of a new phrase: 'Tiger proofing'. This was the concerted effort of course designers to toughen up their courses to unprecedented degrees for fear of Woods making them look his mere playgrounds. Even Augusta National succumbed.

Yet still this is not the full story. Woods's ability to produce the utterly spectacular and sometimes seemingly impossible had a cosmic air.

Take, for example, his tee shot at the 16th hole at the Phoenix Open in 1997. Playing as a rookie professional at the rowdiest, most intimidating hole in golf, surrounded by thousands of baying, drunken college students, Woods's 9-iron from 162 yards was pure, right at the flagstick, bounced twice and dropped in for an ace. Cue pandemonium, with pints of beer hurled in the air like boozy confetti and a screaming Woods raising the roof, conducting the celebrations.

There was also his shot in the dark at the final hole in Firestone in 2000. Weather delays meant he had to finish his round in the near pitch black, but at 8.30pm Woods somehow hit his 8-iron to two feet to seal victory. His ball appeared 'out of a dark sky as suddenly as if Scotty had just beamed it down from the Starship Enterprise,' wrote Sports Illustrated's Gary van Sickle.

And then there is the most famous shot of all time. Battling with Chris DiMarco down the stretch at the 2005 Masters, Woods overshot the 16th green and faced a daunting chip. He was forced to play at a strange angle away from the hole, rolling his ball to the very top of a slope in the green, judging it perfectly so that it trundled back down again towards the pin. The ball gathered momentum and tracked straight towards its target, before stopping agonisingly on the edge of the cup, the crowd both sighing with disappointment and blowing at the ball in the hope of one final roll. Roll it did, exposing the Nike tick in perfect clarity as it dropped into the hole for a quite incredible birdie and, as Woods went on to win in a play-off, marketing that money simply couldn't buy. But then you've already seen that – Nike made sure you did, over and over.

Nike weren't even interested in golf until they discovered Woods. But after discovering this unique opportunity the company then spent hundreds of millions of dollars on launching a golf clothing and equipment division to capitalise on his extraordinary talent. Many more corporate millions followed into his bank account, from Rolex to Gilette, EA Sports, AT&T and Accenture. Even after losing many of his sponsors in the wake of his sex scandal, Forbes estimate that Woods has earned around $1.7billion during his career. Just to emphasise what a big deal he was, just ponder this: only a tenth of that figure was earned on the course. Yet that still amounts to $111,489,339, according to the PGA Tour.

'Tiger will do more than any other man in history to change the course of humanity,' once claimed his father and mentor, Earl. And while that seems, and did seem at the time, ridiculous, Woods represented something far more significant than golf, or any sport for that matter.

A black, working-class man dominating a game previously seen as a rich, white man's preserve made him the biggest story in all of sport. He was smashing down racial and cultural barriers every week, as the first African-American to win the Masters and by winning relentlessly at ultra-conservative country clubs where he would not even have been allowed to play just a few years previously, simply because of the colour of his skin. 

 

Another one of Earl Woods's predictions has become famous, more so over the course of the decade since his son's last major victory. 'I'm going to make a prediction,' he said on the night Tiger won his third US Amateur Championship. 'Before he's through, my son will win 14 major championships.'

With each major that slips away, each missed putt and each pained grimace, Earl's prediction gains the sort of accuracy that Tiger would now kill to have with that erratic driver of his.

But even as his powers diminish, the memory of Woods's accomplishments compels us to want more, to believe against all odds that he can if not beat Nicklaus's record then at least capture one last major. It seems fanciful. Just a few months ago it was uncertain whether Woods would even walk again, let alone play golf, so bad was the chronic deterioration in his back.

And yet he is walking. He is playing golf. He is actually playing very good golf. And if he ever gets a sniff of another major, you'd better believe he can win. He still believes. After all, only one man can truly ever walk down a fairway telling himself: 'I am Tiger Woods.'

HOW TIGER WOODS WON ALL OF HIS 14 MAJORS 

THE MASTERS 

1997

The win that shocked the world. Woods claimed his first major by an enormous 12 strokes, from Tom Kite. And that after scoring 40 for his opening 9 holes before sparking into life. His 18-under-par score remains a record. He was the youngest Masters winner (21) and the first non-white winner.

2001

It was a surprise it took four years for Augusta win No 2 to come along, but this one completed the 'Tiger Slam' – when Woods held all four major titles at once, having won the other three consecutively the previous year. Woods held off big rivals David Duval and Phil Mickelson to win.

2002

The Augusta suits had started to 'Tiger-proof' the course by adding length but could not stop him retaining the green jacket, a feat only managed by Jack Nicklaus (in 1966) and Nick Faldo (in 1990) before. Heavyweights in Retief Goosen, Mickelson and Jose Maria Olazabal were left trailing.

2005

The 16th green in the final round saw arguably the most famous shot ever played: Woods's chip sent away from the hole, rolling up the slope and then back down again at a right angle before hanging on the edge of the cup then finally dropping for birdie. A play-off win over Chris DiMarco followed.

US OPEN 

2000

Tiger at the very peak of his powers; a 15-shot victory at Pebble Beach that was and is the most dominant performance ever witnessed. He was the only player to finish under par (-12) and became the first player in the history of the US Open to finish at double-digits under par for the tournament.

2002

For the first time in 30 years a player won both the masters and US Open consecutively, setting up a tilt at the calendar Grand Slam (later ruined by horrific weather at Muirfield.) Here, Woods tamed the feared Bethpage Black course in New York, beating poor Mickelson once again by three.

2008

The final and most remarkable major win of Woods's career to date. Doubling over in pain after every shot due to playing with a double stress fracture in his left leg, Woods scrambled into a play-off with a birdie on the 72nd hole. He repeated the trick the next day to break Rocco Mediate's heart.

THE OPEN 

2000

At the Home of Golf, Woods became just the fifth player ever to wrap up the career Grand Slam, and the youngest ever aged 24. He blew away Ernie Els and Thomas Bjorn to win by eight on the Old Course at St Andrews, setting a new low score for any major championship of 19 under par.

2005

Woods again proved himself the master of St Andrews, the historic venue considered the most prized place at which to win an Open. He led wire-to-wire, opening with a six-under-par 66 before holding off the final-round challenge from home favourite Colin Montgomerie to win the Claret Jug.

2006

After the death of his father and mentor, Earl, just two months earlier, Woods produced a stunning, controlled performance at Hoylake, eschewing his driver in favour of hitting his 'stinger' long iron off the tee. After his two-shot win over Chris Di Marco was sealed, Woods dissolved into floods of tears.

US PGA CHAMPIONSHIP 

1999

Woods's second major was sealed after a tumultuous battle with Sergio Garcia, whose fiery antics at Medinah started a long and often unfriendly rivalry. Woods held off the teenage Spaniard by just one shot, and many predicted they would duel in many majors to come, which never came to pass.

2000

The Wanamaker Trophy was retained after a play-off win at Valhalla over the unlikely candidate of Bob May, who never won on the PGA Tour, with Thomas Bjorn five shots adrift. It was the first time since Ben Hogan in 1953 that anyone had won three majors in a single year.

2006

Woods finished five shots clear of Shaun Micheel, the shock 2003 champion, with old rival Garcia one further back once again at Medinah, and Luke Donald was the major challenger before falling away at the last. Here, Woods became the first ever to win the US PGA twice on the same course.

2007

The players roasted in 100-degree heat during a heatwave in Oklahoma and at one stage in the final round Woods's lead was whittled down to just one shot, but his mental fortitude again proved decisive. He retained the title at Southern Hills by two shots from Woody Austin.

item.title: Brazil stars touch down in Sochi ahead of World Cup campaign as hotel staff welcome suited and booted squad with cakes, flags and traditional costumes
item.description: Brazil have made their entrance in Russia ahead of the World Cup - and, naturally, they did it in style. Suited and booted, the Selecao arrived at their tournament based in the resort of Sochi.
item.content:encoded:
Brazil have made their entrance in Russia ahead of the World Cup - and, naturally, they did it in style.

Smartly dressed in team issue blue suits, shirts and ties, the stars of the Selecao touched down in Sochi, their headquarters for an assault on a sixth World Cup title over the next five weeks.

The team's star Neymar was to the fore as the squad stepped from the plane that had flown them to Sochi from Vienna, where they defeated Austria 3-0 in their final warm-up ahead of the tournament.


Local fans who'd waited at the airport in Sochi late into the night waved the national flag as the players and coaching staff boarded a coach to head to their team hotel.

The Brazilians are staying at the luxury Swissotel Resort Sochi Kamelia in the Black Sea resort, a five-star hotel where rooms cost £600 a night.

The hotel's staff, some dressed in traditional Russian costume, pulled out all the stops to welcome the Brazilian stars, waving flags, singing and even offering up local delicacies.

New Manchester United signing Fred posted an Instagram snap of a cake iced in the famous Brazilian green and gold as he checked out the new surroundings.

Brazil's World Cup base is certainly stunning and even the weather will make it a home-from-home for the Samba stars with Sochi enjoying more sunshine than any other part of the country.

The resort faces onto the Black Sea with stunning views from one of the 20 luxurious suites and the flower-shaped swimming pool.

Tite and his squad will use the nearby Yug-Sport Stadium for their daily training sessions but the down-side of staying in Sochi is the considerable travel distance to their matches.

Brazil open their World Cup campaign against Switzerland in Rostov on Sunday evening, then make the long journey north to Saint-Petersburg to play Costa Rica on June 22 and then Moscow to face Serbia on June 27.

Having qualified from the notoriously tough South American group with ease, Brazil are considered among the favourites to lift the trophy in Russia.

item.title: Rafael Nadal clutches his French Open trophy after winning 11th title but says he is determined to improve his game: 'You never know where the limit is'
item.description: in a picture posted to his official Instagram account, Rafael Nadal embraced the French Open's famous Coupe des Mousquetaires as if it was the very first time.
item.content:encoded:
Rafael Nadal could be forgiven for getting tired of holding the French Open's Coupe des Mousquetaires. After all, following Sunday's victory over Dominic Thiem, he has now claimed it an incredible 11 times.

But, in a picture posted to his official Instagram account, the 32-year-old Spaniard appeared to embrace the famous trophy as if it was the very first time.

'Amazing feeling!,' is how he described the emotion of winning his 17th grand slam title, leaving him just three behind the all-time record-holder and long-time rival Roger Federer.


Nadal was at his best as he beat arguably the second-best clay-court player in the world, Thiem, in straight sets (6-4, 6-3, 6-2) on Roland Garros's Court Philippe-Chatrier and now heads to Wimbledon firmly placed as world No 1. 

Whether he can ever think about the prospect of catching or even overtaking the Swiss maestro is a question only he can answer, but he seemed determined to carry on at the highest level by admitting he feels there are areas of his game to improve.

'You can always improve something, and I think that everyone can improve,' he said.

'There is no limit. You never know where the limit is. So no-one can tell you where is the limit, so each of us has his or her limitations. 

'But if you don't have the will to improve, you don't understand the sport, because the sport is always about improving. That's the meaning of sport.

'It's playing with the dream of doing something better than what you're doing before. 

'When you're not working with passion of doing something better, I think that sports will lose its sense.'

item.title: Liverpool were so close to sealing £53m Nabil Fekir move they 'allowed France star to pick his own squad number' before deal for Lyon man dramatically collapsed
item.description: Liverpool were so confident their £53million signing of Lyon's Nabil Fekir was on the verge of going through they allowed him to choose his shirt number.
item.content:encoded:
Liverpool were so confident their £53million signing of Lyon's Nabil Fekir was going to be completed that they allowed him to choose his shirt number.

France international Fekir had even conducted interviews with the Anfield club's in-house media team before the move dramatically collapsed on Friday.

It is understood issues arose during the course of Fekir's medical that made Liverpool think twice and the five-year deal, worth more than £140,000-per-week, fell through.


Fekir, who scored 23 goals for Lyon in Ligue 1 last season, was Jurgen Klopp's prime target for the summer and had been identified as a long-term replacement for Philippe Coutinho.

The deal had been struck by sporting director Michael Edwards and, according to French newspaper L'Equipe, Fekir was allowed to select his squad number.

Although the publication didn't specify which number Fekir would choose, eight and 10 are currently vacant in the Liverpool squad list.

Lyon posted a statement confirming the deal had fallen through on their website, though it was later taken down.

It read: 'Olympique Lyonnais informs that the tripartite negotiations with the Liverpool club and Nabil Fekir for the transfer of the captain of OL have not succeeded and that Lyon has decided to put an end to this negotiation on Saturday night.

'Although Liverpool has been the priority of a possible transfer of Nabil, and subject to other proposals consistent with the interest of Nabil and OL and from ambitious clubs, Lyon is delighted soon to be able to count on the presence of the captain who is a leading rookie for this season 2018-2019 during which the club will play the Champions League being in the 3rd hat of the draw.'

item.title: Roma keeper Alisson drops hint his future will be resolved before start of World Cup as Liverpool and Real Madrid chase Brazil star
item.description: In-demand Brazilian goalkeeper Alisson hopes his club future will be sorted out before the World Cup starts later this week. The Roma keeper has been linked to Liverpool and Real Madrid
item.content:encoded:
In-demand Brazilian goalkeeper Alisson hopes his club future will be sorted out before the World Cup starts later this week.

The Roma stopper has been linked with Liverpool, Chelsea and Real Madrid following an excellent season for the Champions League semi-finalists.

Though he is contracted to Roma until 2021, Alisson is likely to move this summer and he is keen to hear news before the tournament starts in Russia.


'I believe and I hope that everything will be resolved before the start of the World Cup,' he said following Brazil's 3-0 friendly win over Austria on Sunday.

'To be honest, I left everything in the hands of my agents.

'If it's not resolved before the World Cup, then it will be discussed after it because my head will be focused only on Brazil.

'There are many possibilities on which we are working, but always together with Roma and with respect to my club. We will see what will happen this week.'

Alisson, 25, kept 22 clean sheets in 49 outings for Roma in Serie A and the Champions League last season, helping them to the semi-finals of the European competition against the odds.

He is likely to be Brazil's No 1 when they begin their World Cup campaign against Switzerland on Sunday.

item.title: 'I thought it was going to blow:' Lewis Hamilton didn't think Mercedes engine would survive Canadian Grand Prix
item.description: Hamilton is braced for a painful week after he lost his championship lead to Vettel in Canada on Sunday. Hamilton now trails Vettel by one point after the Ferrari driver marched to victory.
item.content:encoded:
Lewis Hamilton is braced for a painful week after he lost his championship lead to Sebastian Vettel in Canada on Sunday.

Hamilton now trails Vettel by one point after the dominant Ferrari driver marched to victory at the Circuit Gilles Villeneuve.

Hamilton could finish only fifth as he was left to rue Mercedes' failure to bring a planned engine upgrade to Montreal.

DRIVER TEAM WINS POINTS
1. Sebastian Vettel Ferrari 3 121
2. Lewis Hamilton Mercedes 2 120
3. Valtteri Bottas Mercedes 2 86
4. Daniel Ricciardo Red Bull 0 84
5. Kimi Raikkonen Ferrari 0 68
6. Max Verstappen Red Bull 0 50

The Brit reported he was down on power in the opening exchanges, and had to pit earlier than planned as his Mercedes team made changes to his overheating machinery.

Hamilton was overtaken by Daniel Ricciardo during the pit stops, and feared his seven-race-old engine would not make it the chequered flag.

'I thought it was going to blow,' Hamilton said.

'That's why if I'm really honest, I'm sure the next couple of days it will get more painful.

'Every single lap I was waiting for the power to just drop away and disappear - but it kept going.

'It was ultimately a poor weekend for me, but it could have been a lot worse. I could have failed to finish and lose 25 points to Vettel.'

Mercedes have dominated the sport since 2014, but the fiercer competition provided by both Ferrari and Red Bull this year has led to a series of errors by the once-dominant team.

A timing glitch during a virtual safety car period cost Hamilton the win in Australia before a gearbox issue resulted in a grid drop for the Briton at the next round in Bahrain.

Mercedes can also be accused of playing it safe when they did not bring Hamilton in for new tyres following a late safety car in China.

And here, their failure to provide Hamilton with a fresh engine has contributed to him losing the championship lead.

'This is a major wake-up call for every single member of the team,' Mercedes boss Toto Wolff added on Sunday night.

'I'm the opposite of confident moving forward. Everybody needs to assess how to improve our performance.

'This year's championship is going to be decided by the one who makes the least mistakes. This is the new reality.

'It is a three-way team fight and six cars can win races. We cannot take anything for granted and think it is going to be a walk in the park.'

item.title: Marcel Desailly, Cafu and Harry Kewell try to convince Andrea Pirlo to support their country at World Cup... but will icon of game follow England instead?
item.description: Andrea Pirlo has been left in a pickle after Italy failed to qualify for the World Cup. With the World Cup kicking off later this week, Pirlo admitted he was struggling to look forward to it without Italy.
item.content:encoded:
Andrea Pirlo has been left in a pickle after Italy failed to qualify for the World Cup.

But in a campaign, a series of legends of the game, like Marcel Desailly, Cafu and Harry Kewell have tried to recruit Pirlo to support their own national teams.

With the World Cup kicking off later this week, Pirlo admitted he was struggling to look forward to it without Italy being involved. 


Pirlo said: 'For the first time I can remember, I was not looking forward to the FIFA World Cup this year. I thought "No Italy, no party" but there is still a summer full of football for me to enjoy as a fan at home.

'Without Italy at the tournament, I need a new team to support and I'm looking forward to meeting with some of the most respected footballers in history to help me make a decision.' 

The players have already been pitching their teams to Pirlo as part of an UberEATS campaign. 

1998 FIFA World Cup winner Desailly said: 'It's been 20 years since France's golden generation last won the FIFA World Cup, and this year I believe our new talented team will lift the trophy again. 

'Pirlo if you want to back the winners, France is your team.'

While Crawley Town manager Kewell, formerly of Leeds and Liverpool, added: 'Andrea should take the opportunity to do something different this year and support an underdog, and there's no better underdog than the Aussies. 

'I fancy us to get past the group stages this year and anything can happen from there.'

Cafu also posed alongside the ex-Juventus man in an attempt to get him to support Brazil.

item.title: Eden Hazard says Belgium's golden generation must perform at World Cup in Russia: 'If we want to do something great it is now, not in two or four years'
item.description: Eden Hazard says Belgium's golden generation have to 'do something great' at this year's World Cup because they won't have such squad strength again.
item.content:encoded:
Eden Hazard says Belgium's golden generation have to 'do something great' at this year's World Cup because they won't have such squad strength again.

The No 3 ranked nation in the world, featuring talented players such as Hazard, Kevin de Bruyne and Romelu Lukaku, have never had a better chance to make an impact in the tournament.

Hazard ended the season strongly with Chelsea, helping them beat Manchester United to win the FA Cup, and he is eager to continue that form into the tournament in Russia.


Belgium have been drawn against England, Tunisia and Panama in their World Cup group and are tipped to progress deep into the competition.

'I think that we are all in top shape,' Hazard said. 'Kevin at Manchester City, Romelu at Manchester United, me at Chelsea, Thibaut [Courtois] at Chelsea.

'We all play in great clubs, we all had good seasons. So if we want to do something great, it is now.

'The time isn't in one, two or four years. I think now is the moment to be together and do something great.'

After scoring 17 goals and contributing 13 assists for Chelsea last season, Hazard comes to Russia in excellent form, but he insists the national side aren't reliant on him.

'There is no "Eden Hazard dependence". We have 23 players who can play,' he added.

'Obviously, I am in good shape. I can score and be decisive in the group. There is always a player who is more in the spotlight than the others. It's normal.

'But I think every player can find the solution in games. I could play badly in one game and someone else could score or do the right things.

'Everyone is working for everybody. Everybody is crucial.'

item.title: Patrick Vieira confirmed as manager of Ligue 1 side Nice in his first managerial job in Europe after Arsenal legend leaves New York City FC
item.description: New Nice coach Vieira insists he does not want to be judged on his glittering playing career after taking over the hotseat at the Ligue 1 club. He has left New York City to replace Lucien Favre in France.
item.content:encoded:
New Nice coach Patrick Vieira insists he does not want to be judged on his glittering playing career after taking over the hotseat at the Ligue 1 club.

The former Arsenal skipper left his post as head coach of Major League Soccer side New York City to replace Lucien Favre at the Allianz Riviera.

The 41-year-old Frenchman had been linked with replacing Arsene Wenger at Arsenal following his departure but he now returns to his homeland to take charge of a Nice side that finished eighth last season.

After joining the Gunners in 1996, Vieira went on to win three Premier League titles, including captaining the club during their unbeaten 'Invincibles' campaign of 2003/04.

He would then win four successive Serie A titles at Inter Milan before lifting a fourth FA Cup of his career having returned to England with Manchester City.

Add to that a 1998 World Cup winners' medal and success at Euro 2000 and Vieira's distinguished career is one that many will remember.


But the man himself is keen to put that to one side as he looks to build on the work he did as the Manchester City academy boss and during his two and a half year stint with NYCFC.

'My career as a player no longer counts, it's part of the past,' he told reporters at his unveiling on Monday afternoon.

'The important thing for me is to have a clear idea of what I want from players, a specific game scheme for them to express themselves, because the talent is there.

'I'm happy. This is what I was looking for: I will work in good conditions with passionate people, who will support me in the good and bad times. I am very happy to be here. There is everything you need here to succeed.'

Announcing Vieira's departure on their official website, New York City were quick to thank their former coach for his endeavours.

'New York City FC today announced that Head Coach Patrick Vieira is leaving the Club to join OGC Nice, effective immediately,' the club's statement read.

'Vieira departs after two and a half years at the helm having led the team to two consecutive play-off appearances and with a current second place standing in the Eastern Conference.'

David Villa, NYCFC's most high-profile player and another man to have lifted both a World Cup and a European Championship title, tweeted his own message to Vieira.

'Thank you for everything you've done for the club, @OfficialVieira. You are not only a great coach but also a fantastic person. It was an honor to play for you and your staff (Christian Lattanzio, Kristian Wilson & Matthew Cook). Wishing you all the best in your future endeavors (sic),' he wrote.

There are also some big names waiting for Vieira in southern France with former Manchester City team-mate Mario Balottelli the stand-out talent.

The controversial Italy international hit 26 goals for Nice last season and has been linked with a summer move to rivals Marseille.

But Vieira revealed he has spoken to the 27-year-old and expects the forward to be present for pre-season training.

'I called Mario Balotelli to wish him a happy holiday,' he added.

'Also to tell him that we would see each other on July 2nd at the resumption of training. But I take one thing at a time.'

item.title: Toto Wolff claims Mercedes need 'major wake-up call' while Lewis Hamilton 'super grateful' to finish after toiling to fifth in Canadian Grand Prix
item.description: Hamilton saw his 14-point championship lead wiped out after a dominant Sebastian Vettel marched to victory at the Circuit Gilles Villeneuve to move top of the drivers' standings for Ferrari.
item.content:encoded:
Lewis Hamilton's thrashing in Canada must act as a 'major wake-up call' to Mercedes, Toto Wolff said on Sunday night.

Hamilton saw his 14-point championship lead wiped out after a dominant Sebastian Vettel marched to victory at the Circuit Gilles Villeneuve.

Indeed Vettel now leads Hamilton by one point after the British driver was left to rue a Mercedes engine problem as he finished an underwhelming fifth.

Unlike all their rivals, Mercedes failed to bring a planned engine upgrade to Montreal - and it would cost Hamilton dearly.

The Briton, running on a seven-race-old engine, reported he was down on power in the opening exchanges, and had to pit earlier than planned as his Mercedes team made changes to his overheating machinery.


Hamilton, fourth at the time, headed into the pit lane on lap 16 of this 70-lap race, but the early stop allowed Daniel Ricciardo to usurp the Mercedes car.

Mercedes have dominated the sport since 2014, but the fiercer competition provided by both Ferrari and Red Bull this year has led to a series of errors.

A timing glitch during a virtual safety car period cost Hamilton the win in Australia before a gearbox issue resulted in a grid drop for the Briton at the next round in Bahrain.

Mercedes can also be accused of playing it safe when they did not bring Hamilton in for new tyres following a late safety car in China.

And here, their failure to give Hamilton a fresh engine has contributed to him losing the championship lead.

'This is a major wake-up call for every single member of the team,' Mercedes boss Wolff said. 'I'm the opposite of confident moving forward.

'Everybody needs to assess how to improve our performance.

'This year's championship is going to be decided by the one who makes the least mistakes. This is the new reality.

'It is a three-way team fight and six cars can win races. We cannot take anything for granted and think it is going to be a walk in the park.'

F1 DRIVERS' STANDINGS
DRIVER TEAM WINS POINTS
1. Sebastian Vettel Ferrari 3 121
2. Lewis Hamilton Mercedes 2 120
3. Valtteri Bottas Mercedes 2 86
4. Daniel Ricciardo Red Bull 0 84
5. Kimi Raikkonen Ferrari 0 68
6. Max Verstappen Red Bull 0 50

Hamilton added: 'I could have lost a lot more points here. I am super-grateful I finished. I was down on power, and every single lap I was on edge waiting for the power to drop away.

'We have got to keep working, and keep pushing because Ferrari will falter if we can apply the pressure.'

Vettel claimed the Scuderia's first victory in Canada since Michael Schumacher triumphed here 14 years ago, and his first win in five races.

His success was never in doubt after he surged off the starting line and controlled the race - despite the chequered flag accidentally being waved one lap early by Canadian model Winnie Harlow - to apply the championship pressure back on to Hamilton.

item.title: Eden Hazard wants clarity over managerial situation at Chelsea as his own future hangs in the balance
item.description: Eden Hazard wants to know who will be in charge of Chelsea next season and has suggested that his future at the club could be affected by it.
item.content:encoded:
Eden Hazard wants to know who will be in charge of Chelsea next season and has suggested that his future at the club could be affected by it. 

There has been much speculation surrounding Antonio Conte's future at Stamford Bridge and failure to guide them to Champions League qualification last season will have seen the Italian come under more scrutiny. 

However, after being linked with a move away from the Premier League side for months, Conte could well likely see out the year that is left on his contract as Roman Abramovich looks to keep costs down.


Former Napoli coach Maurizio Sarri looked to be the favourite to replace Conte but a move now looks off the cards.

Immediately after Chelsea's triumph in the FA Cup last month, Hazard cast doubt over his future with the club and it appears that the Belgian star will not decide where he will end up until the situation becomes clearer.

The 27-year-old has two years left on his current deal with Chelsea. 

'Yeah, I want to know,' Hazard told reporters. 'I want to know, but like I say I am focused on the World Cup.

'If we have something new – manager or players – it is always good to know it, because I want players that can [help bring success back to] Chelsea next season.

'But, to be fair, the transfer market is not here yet. We will see after.'

item.title: Cristiano Ronaldo and Co pose in Portugal strip for photoshoot after touching down in Russia for World Cup
item.description: The Portugal star posed for several cheeky snaps in the national side's kit ahead of the World Cup. He was joined by Ricardo Quaresma and Gelson Martins at the portrait session on Sunday.
item.content:encoded:
Cristiano Ronaldo has taken part in a photoshoot after touching down in Russia this week ahead of the World Cup.

The Portugal star posed for several cheeky snaps in the national side's kit ahead of the World Cup.

Ronaldo was joined by team-mates Ricardo Quaresma and Gelson Martins on Sunday at the FIFA World Cup 2018 portrait session at Saturn Training Base.


The Real Madrid forward was naturally adept in front of the camera while Quaresma and Martins both took a more serious approach with their poses.

The Portugal squad landed in Moscow this week, where they will be based for the tournament, and had their first training session before they kick-off their World Cup campaign on Sunday. 

Despite his club season only concluding on May 26, Ronaldo showed no signs of fatigue as he was put through his paces with his team-mates

The Euro 2016 winners are fine-tuning their preparations at their Moscow base ahead of their World Cup opener against 2010 champions Spain.

There have been plenty of smiles in Portugal's camp recently and unlike a number of sides, their warm-up matches in recent weeks have been promising.

After being held to a 2-2 draw by Tunisia - who are in England's group this summer - last month, they played out a goalless stalemate with Belgium before thumping Algeria 3-0 on Thursday.

Their opening game against Spain could prove decisive in terms of who wins Group B. They face Morocco afterwards on June 20 before taking on Iran in their final group game five days later.

item.title: Tyson Fury ordered to lose more weight ahead of next heavyweight bout after Gypsy King breezes to simple victory over Sefer Seferi
item.description: JEFF POWELL: Tyson Fury is under orders to lose yet more poundage and brace himself for a real heavyweight opponent when he makes his second reappearance, in Belfast this summer.
item.content:encoded:
Tyson Fury is under orders to lose yet more poundage and brace himself for a real heavyweight opponent when he makes his second reappearance, in Belfast this summer.

Saturday night's first fight of the Gypsy King's comeback bore such close resemblance to an arranged marriage that the kissing couple paused during their brief encounter to watch a livelier altercation among their guests outside the ring.

The result, the waving of a white towel in the opposite corner before the start of the fifth round, was a foregone conclusion which made the betting odds of 1-1000 on a Fury victory seem positively generous.

So much smaller, lighter, over-powered, over-awed and over-matched was the hitherto unknown Sefer Seferi that the aged Albanian cruiserweight had no more chance of beating Fury than our family cat of winning Crufts.

Fury would have been in the dog-house had the people not known he had gone almost barking with depression during the near-one-thousands days of drug abuse and booze bingeing since his amazing wresting of the unified world heavyweight crown from the long-reigning Wladimir Klitschko.


Given all his psychological traumas, the near-15,000 crowd in the Manchester Arena were prepared to smile upon the Pagliacci clowning which betrayed the nerves he admitted suffering 'before what felt like another debut.' Promoter Frank Warren knows there would be reduced public tolerance of a repeat performance.

Fury was still carrying excess blubber despite shedding eight stones and Warren said: 'Tyson needs to lose even more weight before he fights on Carl Frampton's card at Windsor Park on August 18. He is also aware there will be a higher calibre opponent.

'We didn't try to kid anyone that Seferi was anything other than someone to help him ease into his comeback. Taking off all those stones in less than three months is physically draining and he also had to start shaking off the ring rust after such a long lay-off.' The clamour for Fury to set about regaining the several belts he gave over to Anthony Joshua will be resisted until next summer.

'Tyson needs more time and more fights,' says Warren. In any event Joshua, WBC champion Deontay Wilder and even WBA 'regular' tile holder Manuel Charr - who failed to materialise at ringside as promised - are otherwise occupied until then. Not least with each other in the case of AJ and Bronze Bomber Wilder.

Nor is Fury likely to take up Tony Bellew's challenge next. Fury says: 'After this one against Seferi I need a big heavyweight, not another small opponent.' 

'One step at a time,' counsels Warren. Although the next one must be over a higher hurdle than Seferi, who at ten inches shorter and more than four and a half stone lighter was dwarfed by the 6ft 9in and 19st 10lbs Manchester traveller.

So pleased was Fury to see Seferi that he planted a smacker on his cheek before the off, then another when it all came to a premature end.

For most of the time between those gestures Fury pranced and postured, grinned and grimaced. He also held his arms wide by way of inviting Seferi to hit him if he could. Which he couldn't.

Referee Phil Edwards was not as amused as most of the fans. He instructed Fury to stop playing the comedian and start being a fighter again in earnest.

He chastised them both most severely when they stopped boxing altogether to watch the brawl in the hall.

Fury said: 'I was enjoying myself so much. I loved being back in the big time, beneath the big lights, in front of a big crowd.' 'He might have added: 'Under the big top.' It was a circus until he opened up in the fourth. He ended that round with an uppercut so solid that Seferi chose to quit on his stool.

'That,' said Warren, 'was my only real disappointment. I thought he could and should have continued.' 

Fury said: 'I could have knocked him out in the first ten seconds. But I was saving him for the fifth, which was the round I had told everyone I would stop him.' Anyway, a win is a win. This was the 26th of his undefeated, interrupted career. No doubt the 27th will be forthcoming in that Belfast football ground.

Fury said he would fight Joshua tomorrow. Which purely in the context of no damage sustained and little energy expended on Saturday, he could.

'It's all about entertainment,' says Fury. But as Warren knows, it takes more than a few belly laughs to win world titles.

item.title: Chequered flag blunder costs Daniel Ricciardo, while Hector Bellerin suffers double snub... Five things you missed from the Canadian Grand Prix
item.description: After a huge crash on the opening lap, the Canadian Grand Prix failed to reach any more high dramas as Sebastian Vettel strolled to victory for Ferrari. But here are five things you may have missed.
item.content:encoded:
After a huge crash on the opening lap, the Canadian Grand Prix failed to reach any more high dramas as Sebastian Vettel strolled to victory for Ferrari. 

The German though will be most delighted by the weekend's overall low key events as his win sees him retake the lead in the world championship from Lewis Hamilton.

But what else was there to look out for in Montreal? Sportsmail looks at the five things you may have missed from the race. 


 

Flying the flag... a lap too early

As far as F1 races go, this won't go down as the most memorable 70 laps in grand prix racing history.

In fact history won't even remember it being 70 laps. After model Winnie Harlow, not to her own fault, waved the chequered flag one flap too early it brought the race to an official end at the conclusion of the 68th lap.

There were thankfully no big losers out on the track in terms of places, although Daniel Ricciardo's fastest lap on lap 69 was expunged as a result of the error... handing the prize instead to Red Bull team-mate Max Verstappen.

When you tell @WinnieHarlow to wave the chequered flag too early 🙈

Miscommunications happen!#NoHarmDone pic.twitter.com/3uWCl6zMbG

— Formula 1 (@F1) June 10, 2018

“IT WASNT ME” *Shaggy Voice* when they tell you to wave the flag a lap too early 😂😩😡🏁🏁 but I’m so grateful no one was hurt! 🙏🏽🏎 @F1 pic.twitter.com/2wBmH3SDOP

— ♔Winnie Harlow♔ (@winnieharlow) June 10, 2018
 

Bellerin snubbed by Sky (twice) 

If Hector Bellerin ever wants to spend a weekend incognito, he would be wise to book up another attendance at a Formula One grand prix.

Already snubbed by Spain for this summer's World Cup, the Arsenal full-back was also ignored by broadcasters Sky before the race, with presenter Martin Brundle even asking him to move aside so he could speak to Winnie Harlow instead.

If that wasn't enough Ted Kravitz even failed to recognise who he was when he appeared on the screen after qualifying, saying: 'Some hipsters around here with shaved hair and shorts and cool rose-coloured glasses.

'He looks quite cool, that guy in the singlet, doesn’t he? Right, sorry, I got distracted by the hipsters.'

 

Villeneuve drives late father's Ferrari around the circuit

It was 40 years ago when the famous Gilles Villeneuve claimed his first victory in Montreal while driving for Ferrari.

Fast forward to 2018 and his son, Jacques, had the honour of driving the Ferrari 312 T3 to lead the drivers' on the parade lap.

Although Villeneuve was emotional following the lap, the 1997 world champion had joked before hand of the occasion, saying: 'It's great because it's the first time I will lead in a Formula One car in Montreal!'

 

Hamilton and Alonso bury hatchet

Fernando Alonso and Lewis Hamilton have never been the best of friends and were the bitterest of enemies fighting for the world championship 11 years ago.

But there is plenty of respect between the pair these days, with Hamilton seeking out the Spaniard to shake his hand ahead of Alonso's 300th grand prix.

The pair even stood side-by-side to mark the occasion as the paddock celebrated the two-time world champion's milestone.

 

Why basketball players will never make it in F1 

Even if a basketball player had all the talent needed to become a successful racing driver, there is still one thing holding them back... they can't get in the car!

Toronto Raptor star Serge Ibaka tried to get into Alonso's McLaren during the weekend only to find an F1 cockpit was never going to house a 6ft 10in NBA star.

Just to compound the problem, with knees still sticking out the car, Alonso then offered his steering wheel to his Spanish compatriot which also needed to go in the cockpit.

I definitely think this cars are not made for 6'10 basketball players 😂😂 Ahora ya estoy seguro que estos coches no están hechos para jugadores de baloncesto de 2'10 de altura 😂😂

A post shared by Serge Ibaka (@sergeibaka) on Jun 9, 2018 at 3:56pm PDT

But what else was there to look out for in Montreal? Sportsmail looks at the five things you may have missed from the race.

item.title: Rangers locked in battle with Spartak Moscow for Croatian defender Nikola Katic as Steven Gerrard also looks to wrap up £3m deal for Connor Goldson
item.description: The Ibrox club are poised to finalise a £3million deal for Brighton centre-half Connor Goldson this week, but boss Steven Gerrard also has an interest in Nikola Katic.
item.content:encoded:
Rangers are locked in a battle with Spartak Moscow for the capture of Croatian defender Nikola Katic.

The Ibrox club are poised to finalise a £3million deal for Brighton centre-half Connor Goldson this week.

But boss Steven Gerrard also has an interest in Katic, a former Under-21 international capped for the first time by Croatia's senior side last May.

Croatian club Slaven Belupo are seeking a fee of around £2m for the 21-year-old.


And the defender's agent Mladen Kliskinic will fly to Moscow tomorrow for talks with Russian giants Spartak.

Insisting no formal deal has yet been concluded with any club, however, a spokesman for Kliskinic told Sportsmail: 'There was a representative from Glasgow Rangers in Croatia three weeks ago.

'There is another story that Spartak Moscow are also interested. Mladen Kliskinic has booked a flight to go and speak to them on Tuesday.

'But we are waiting for Slaven Belupo to confirm they've accepted a concrete offer. Until that happens nothing can be finalised.' Goldson, meanwhile, is expected to become Gerrard's fourth signing.

item.title: Vitali Klitschko inducted into the boxing Hall of Fame in Canastota as Mike Tyson and Deontay Wilder attend the ceremony and champions parade
item.description: Vitali Klitschko has been recognised for his success in boxing by officially being inducted into the sport's Hall Of Fame in Canastota, New York.
item.content:encoded:
Vitali Klitschko has been recognised for his success in boxing by officially being inducted into the sport's Hall Of Fame in Canastota, New York.

The Ukrainian former boxer turned politician was afforded the usual procedure of a parade of champions before going through the formal ceremony to have his name placed alongside the legends of yesteryear.

Many decorated pros past and present were in attendance, including his former world champion brother Wladimir and living legend of the sport Mike Tyson.

Scroll down for video 

2018 International Boxing Hall of Fame inductees. #CANASTOTA #IBHOF #KLITSCHKO pic.twitter.com/F2pdg7ugxP

— Klitschko (@Klitschko) June 10, 2018

Deontay Wilder, who is hoping to become the next big thing with a blockbuster showdown with Anthony Joshua next year, was also present to witness the proceedings. 

Klitschko, now 46, ended his storied career with a standing of 45-2, including 41 knock-outs. 


He turned pro in 1996 and went on to win versions of the heavyweight crown three times, even though he was retired from 2005 to 2008 because of injuries.  

After his comeback, he and younger brother Wladimir held all four of the major heavyweight belts simultaneously and dominated the elite level of the sport.

Taking to social media, Wladimir filmed himself standing atop a car during the parade of champions as a gathered crowd watched on and a brass band played.

'Really proud of my brother being inducted her in Canastota into the Hall of Fame,' Wladimir said to the camera.

'It's a great celebration right here, I love Canastota! cheers.'

item.title: Pick of the bunch: How Jordan Pickford went from 'scrawny kid' to England's No 1 for the World Cup
item.description: George Honeyman was in the Black Cats dressing room when O'Shea shared it with the rest of the squad. 'Rooney wrote, "Hasn't said a word!",' reveals the midfielder.
item.content:encoded:
Jordan Pickford was on the England team bus for the first time in 2016 when captain Wayne Rooney took a sneaky picture on his mobile phone. The snap was sent to John O'Shea, a team-mate of the young goalkeeper at Sunderland.

George Honeyman was in the Black Cats dressing-room when O'Shea shared it with the rest of the squad. 'Rooney wrote in the message, "Hasn't said a word!",' reveals the midfielder, a pal of Pickford since the age of 11 at the club's academy.

'It was funny, Jordan was so lively at Sunderland, he never shut up. But he'd gone there and not spoken at all - we found it quite unusual!'


The ribbing did not end there, as Honeyman recalls: 'Jordan's not the type to brag, but he came back into training with us and let slip something about 'Wazza'. He got a bit of stick for that.'

Less than two years on and that impressionable rookie is England's No 1, becoming the most expensive keeper in British history last summer when he joined Everton for £30million.

He will earn just his fourth cap when he lines up against Tunisia next Monday for England's World Cup opener in Volgograd.

Speak to those who know Pickford best, however, and they will tell you that such inexperience will not faze the 24-year-old.

Honeyman was on FaceTime with him earlier this week and says he is 'raring to go'. But that, it would appear, has always been his way.

'I played with him all the way through and he's always been such a fierce competitor,' adds Honeyman.

'He had his mood swings if he didn't get his own way, but the main reason he has succeeded is how competitive and aggressive he is.

'Off the pitch, he's the life and soul, no-one dislikes him. Everyone says goalkeepers are mad, but he genuinely is, he's a nutter, in the nicest way.

'He loves his boxing, motocross, golf, he's just a full-on, fun guy to be around.'

Former Sunderland academy boss Kevin Ball was still club captain when he first met Pickford, then a five-year-old autograph hunter sticking his pen and pad through his hero's car window.

Born in working-class surrounds in Washington - eight miles from the Stadium of Light - Pickford was a Sunderland fanatic, just like his builder dad, Lee, and his mother, Sue.

'He asked for my autograph and a photo and said I was his favourite player,' remembers Ball, now a club ambassador.

'He showed me that picture years later and asked if I recognised who was in it. I said, "Well, the handsome one is obviously me, and I'm guessing that scrawny little kid is you?".'

Ball's relationship with his talented teenager was not always so jovial, as Honeyman recalls with a smile.

'We were away at Blackburn and Bally was giving Jordan a bit of stick for one of their goals,' he says.

'Bally had a habit of it being his way or the highway and they started arguing. Bally said, "You'll never make it with that attitude". Jordan just stared straight back at him and said, "I bet I will".

'Normally when Bally was shouting at players they'd wither and cave in. Not Jordan - he dared him to bet against him. We knew then that it would be Jordan who was proved right.'

Ball recalls the same tale with affection rather than anger, but adds: 'I had to make him understand where he was and what he needed to do to get to where he wanted to be.

'He thought he was the best. He knew he had potential and athletic ability. But you have to work hard to achieve that, and he has.

'He wanted to be in the first-team at 17 and was pushy, but I liked that. He challenged me.'

Pickford rang Ball on the morning of his senior debut to say 'thank you'. He is, it seems, a young man who will never forget his roots.

He now lives on Merseyside with his childhood sweetheart Megan Davison but made a point of returning to the North-East to collect his Football Writers' Young Player of the Year award in February. The comedian that night was, at times, as blue as Everton's jersey, but Pickford laughed along heartily, later taking time to chat to Sunderland fans. Earlier, it had been his turn to oblige with a queue of autograph hunters.

'He's a typical, down-to-earth local lad, there is no arrogance to him, it's all confidence,' says Adrian Tucker, the former Sunderland goalkeeping coach who worked with Pickford after his first-team breakthrough.

Remarkably, that did not arrive until January 2016, coming on the back of loan spells and more than 100 appearances at Darlington, Alfreton, Burton, Carlisle, Bradford and Preston.

'What I love about him is his mental strength,' says Tucker. 'We used to play golf together and I would give him a thrashing, but he got over it - he'd always come back for more.

'I remember going to watch him when he was on loan at Bradford against Yeovil. In the first five minutes he got absolutely clattered by their big centre-forward. The first thing he did was get straight back up. I thought, "You'll do for me, son".'

It was not always Pickford being clattered, however. Sunderland's juniors were away at Crystal Palace one afternoon when his usually dependable kicking let him down.

What followed has stayed with Honeyman, and he laughs as he begins: 'He mishit this clearance and it's obviously annoyed him. It wasn't going to make halfway. Jordan has realised and gone steaming out, chasing after it.

'The ball landed with their player on about the centre circle and he was just getting himself composed, unaware that Jordan was running towards him at full speed.

'Honestly, it was one of the best tackles I've ever seen! He's sent their guy absolutely flying but won the ball with it. He wiped him out, I don't think the lad recovered. But that's Jordan - determination, pride in himself and confidence.'

Keeping Pickford within the confines of his penalty area was a constant issue for Ball, and not because he was prone to a rush of blood. Far from it, it was more because of his composure than a lack of it, those skills honed playing in the street with older brother Richard Logan, a one-time striker for Darlington.

'We had one session where we put the goalkeeper at centre-back, just to help them understand the game from the position directly in front of them,' says Ball.

'Jordan was unbelievable. He was just as good as an outfield player because of that natural footballing talent with his feet. The way he can strike a ball with pace and accuracy… But that also became a problem. We wanted to play the ball out from the back and the keepers had to use the defenders.

'I remember Jordan pinging the ball 50 yards to the right-winger with his first touch. I said, "What you doing, we want to play out from the back?". He said, "Yeah, but I'm better than them". I looked at him and thought, "Yeah, you're probably right".'

Honeyman, too, recalls his friend's playing ambitions. 'He was always desperate to go outfield during training,' he says. 'It got to the point where it annoyed everyone - we were like, "Jordan, just get in goal".

'But even at Under-16s we were getting bigger crowds because people were coming just to watch him, and that never happens for a goalkeeper. They used to come just to see his kicking. That showed how special he was, even back then.'

Pickford was pulling onto his mother's driveway in October 2016 when he got the call to say he had been selected for England. Sue did not believe her son when he entered the terraced family home and delivered the shock news. They certainly believe him now.

'He totally deserves this,' says Honeyman. 'It seemed to take him longer than we thought to be Sunderland's No 1. He should have been a few years earlier.

'But he's still done exceptionally well to achieve this so quickly. I look back at us, as kids, and we just knew he would go to the very top.'

Ball finishes with some advice. 'Jordan has the ability to be one of the world's best goalkeepers,' he says. 'What he has achieved so far is fabulous, now he has to challenge himself again, and I'm sure he will, he won't stop, that's what I love about him.'
